name: Cyclocross - Moderate Volume - 3:1 - Strength
description:
#### Cyclocross - Moderate Volume - 3:1 - Strength


The first step in your journey to getting faster!

​

If you are in need of any technical help or want to know more about the training terms used in this plan check out the [Wahoo SYSTM Help Center.](https://wahoosystm.com/HelpCenter)

​

Have a more specific question that isn't addressed in the Help Center? Head over to our [forum](https://wahoox.forum.wahoofitness.com/) to see if your question has been answered, or just post it for yourself.

​

For any questions on what to expect from your Strength Addon check out [these helpful articles](https://support.wahoofitness.com/hc/en-us/articles/4406401932050).

prospects.name: The Best Thing In The World
prospects.description: Just like a real race, the two race-paced efforts in TBTITW offer few moments of truly “settling” into a steady effort. The constant surging below, at, and well above threshold push your ability to recover to the max, making this a fantastic session for building your Anaerobic Capacity (AC). Since you are often forced to “recover” at high intensities, your cardiovascular system hardly gets a real break, which means your Maximal Aerobic Power (MAP) gets pushed hard too. With each effort ending in an all-out sprint, you really get to test out how much you have left in the tank. You might surprise yourself.

prospects.name: Cadence Builds
prospects.description:
One of the best sessions for neuromuscular training, this drill asks you to progressively build from a cadence of 90 RPM to your MAX over 30 seconds, recover, and repeat several times. Cadence builds improve how you recruit your leg, gluteal, and core muscles throughout your pedal stroke by progressing to your maximal cadence. By reaching your highest cadence possible, you are training the 'on/off' switch in each muscle group to not only work faster but to have less overlap with your other muscle groups. This session trains your hamstring muscles to 'turn off' when your quads 'turn on' and vice-versa, resulting in a more efficient pedal stroke at both high and low cadences.

​

**LEARN MORE**

Listen to The Knowledge podcast, by Wahoo Sports Science - The Benefits of High Cadence Training: [https://wahoosystm.com/BenefitsofHighCadence](https://wahoosystm.com/BenefitsofHighCadence)

prospects.name: Found in America
prospects.description:
🎬 Film (2020): After finishing the Race Across America on the podium, Dave Haase is coming back to win it. But is that what he's really looking for? Is there more to why he's taking on such a formidable challenge than the pursuit of victory alone? This is an honest look at the demands of a legendary ultra-endurance race and what one finds out on the road.

​

🚴 Workout: This is a great way to watch a compelling documentary while developing your baseline aerobic fitness. The intensity of this workout will vary mostly between 60-70% of FTP, with heart rate remaining entirely in zone 2. This session will add minimal fatigue to your system, while still giving your aerobic engine the workload it needs to continue progressing.

​

[Here's how to turn off on-screen graphics for the best viewing experience.](https://wahoosystm.com/HelpCenterInspiration)

prospects.name: MAP Micro Intervals: 3 Sets 40/20s
prospects.description:
For any of you who have completed Blender, Mini Blender, or the Chores, you will be familiar with the 40/20 variety of Pain Shakes that this session serves up

​

40/20s are a go-to workout for Sir Neal Henderson when dishing out pain to the athletes he coaches. While the first few efforts in each set will feel "easy," since these blocks are stretched out to 8-minutes in length, you will be deep into the red by the end of each set.

While the efforts aren't continuous, they are long enough that you will accumulate plenty of time near your VO2max, which is the goal of any MAP workout. The real kicker from this session is how much time you spend at 100% of MAP. Each 8-minute set gives you 5 minutes and 20-seconds of time at your 5-minute peak power. By the end, you are looking at 16 minutes of accumulated MAP efforts, so expect this one to bring some pain!

​

**Warm Up**

1 minute 15 seconds @ RPE 2.5 -- 55% of FTP -- HR <70%

1 minute @ RPE 3.5 -- 65% of FTP -- HR <80%

prospects.name: Igniter
prospects.description:
A highly tuned machine needs its engine warmed up in order to produce the most power as efficiently as possible. Igniter is based on the highly successful warm-up session developed by British Cycling and used by Team Sky as part of their 'marginal gains' program. You'll go through a series of progressive efforts before hitting a couple of high-intensity/high-cadence sprints. You'll emerge ready to CRUSH EVERYTHING BEFORE YOU! This workout is perfect before major events, in conjunction with our Extra Shot workout, or to extend your regular session.

​

**LEARN MORE**

Listen to why warm-ups are so important in this episode of The Knowledge podcast by Wahoo Sports Science:

[https://wahoosystm.com/WarmingupTheEngine](https://wahoosystm.com/WarmingupTheEngine)

prospects.name: Trails: Cruising 2
prospects.description:
**What?**

A trail ride at a cruisy pace.

​

**Why?**

Variety is the spice of life and it’s also the best way to accomplish a few goals simultaneously. Focus on targeting your weaknesses during this trail session in order to improve them come race day.

​

**How?**

This is an unstructured ride - let the trail do the thinking today. If you find a section that you struggle to hit cleanly, repeat that section a few times until you feel comfortable with it. Don’t feel the need to practice every section you struggle with on a single ride, you can always come back another day! Keep the effort below 85% of FTP at all times and spend the bulk of the ride around 60% of FTP.

​

Make sure to warm up well and cool down afterwards.

prospects.name: Costa Blanca: Coll de Rates
prospects.description:
This session is all about building your VO₂ Max power with a focus on pacing. You’ll start with a flat warm-up to get the body ready before diving into a progressive series of ramping intervals. Each interval gets shorter but more intense, pushing your cardiovascular system while keeping your legs working under control. The aim is to help you finish strong — not fade — by learning how to pace properly through effort buildup.

​

Set on the steady slopes of Coll de Rates, the consistent gradient supports rhythm and control, allowing you to focus on cadence, breathing, and technique as you go deeper into the red. The final threshold block adds bonus training stimulus and flushes the legs under fatigue. This is a session that builds smarter, stronger climbers — from both a physical and mental standpoint.

​

[**Wahoo Route**](https://www.strava.com/activities/14035783847)

​

_Your Host: There are few people who know the mountains and roads of Europe better than Wahoo Ambassador Michael Cotty. As founder of The Col Collective, Mike has made a career out of riding, filming, and telling the story of epic rides and mountains across the continent. As your On Location co-creator and host, Mike's engaging character, curious mind, and friendly nature will have you cueing up your next ride with him before you've even finished the cool-down._

prospects.name: Bavaria: Burgberg
prospects.description:
This may be a short workout, but it packs a serious punch—so lace up those gloves and get ready for 22 powerful 10-second seated sprints!

After a gentle warm-up leaving the picturesque village of Sulzberg, we’ll dive straight into our first block: 8 x 10-second high-cadence seated sprints with 50 seconds of recovery.

As the road naturally levels out, we’ll catch our breath before hitting the core of the workout—9 x 10-second low-cadence seated sprints with the same 50-second recovery, focusing on maintaining rock-solid form.

To close things out, we’ll return to the high-cadence style for a final round of 5 x 10-second sprints. This session is designed to sharpen muscle activation and improve recovery after intense efforts.

Finish strong, and I’ll see you in Burgberg!

​

With short near-maximal sprint efforts like these, you’ll recruit all of the muscle fibers in your legs. While cadence builds force your muscles to contract and relax as quickly as possible, this session forces your muscles to contract with maximal power. Just like cadence builds, this session becomes one of the best ways to train your neuromuscular system.

Even if your target event does not require you to complete maximal sprints, there is a substantial trickle-down efficiency effect to the longer-duration power efforts when you train your neuromuscular system.

​

[**Route on Strava**](https://www.strava.com/activities/9866624296)

​

_Your Host: There are few people who know the mountains and roads of Europe better than Wahoo Ambassador Michael Cotty. As founder of The Col Collective, Mike has made a career out of riding, filming, and telling the story of epic rides and mountains across the continent. As your On Location co-creator and host, Mike's engaging character, curious mind, and friendly nature will have you cueing up your next ride with him before you've even finished the cool-down._

prospects.name: Standing Starts into MAP: 5 x 1
prospects.description:
In this session, you will be going straight from a max 20-second high torque starting effort into 40 seconds right at MAP. The Starting effort should just about completely drain your Anaerobic Capacity, which will leave you gasping for air as you start each 40-second MAP effort. By forcing yourself to maintain MAP after a maximal sprint, you are asking your body to increase oxygen supply to your muscles as quickly as possible by increasing your heart rate and breathing rate. Being able to increase oxygen consumption rapidly means your body will better handle changes in pace both above and below threshold.

​

What you need to do:

- You will need to begin each Standing Start at super low RPM's with very high torque (high resistance). To maximize muscle recruitment you want to both push-down and pull-up on the pedals at the start. Proper core engagement is a must, as your legs need a sturdy backboard to push against.
- You'll want the starting resistance to be just high enough that only your max effort can get the pedals moving; after those first few revs your goal is to get your cadence up as high as possible by the end of the 20 seconds. The best way to ensure you have the right resistance is to complete this session in slope mode rather than ERG mode.
- Once the 20-second start is over you want to settle right into the 40-second effort at MAP, avoiding any significant drop in power at the transition point. Since the goal of this 40-second MAP effort is maximal cardiovascular demand, aim to hold your cadence 10-15 RPM higher than you would for the 5-minute test in Full Frontal.

For Time Trialists and Triathletes:

After the Standing Start, you will want to get into your aerobars and hold the same position you will be competing in. Those on regular road bikes should get down into the drops.

​

**Warm Up**

15 minute @ RPE 2 -- 50% of FTP -- HR <70%

2 minutes @ RPE 2.5 -- 55% of FTP -- HR <70%

1 minute @ RPE 3.5 -- 65% of FTP -- HR <80%

1 minute @ RPE 4.5 -- 75% of FTP -- HR <90%

3 minutes @ RPE 2.5 -- 55% of FTP -- HR <70%

​

**Main Effort**

Number of sets: 5

Rest between sets: 15 minutes @ RPE 2 -- 50% of FTP -- HR <70%

Interval repeats per set: NA

**Interval**

20 seconds @ RPE 10 -- 180% of FTP -- HR >105%

40 seconds @ RPE 9 -- 95-105%% of MAP (115-135% of FTP)

​

**Extra Volume**

N/A

​

**Cool Down**

8 minutes @ RPE 1.5 -- 45% of FTP-- HR <70%

prospects.name: UAE Tour 2
prospects.description:
**Featured Rider: **Andrea Vendrame

**Event:** UAE Tour

**Mission - “Sniper”:** It’s Stage 6 of the UAE Tour and the peloton is entering the final 20km of the race. While not an out-and-out sprinter, you’re the fast man of the AG2R Citroen team. You don’t have a leadout so you’re on your own to grab a result. Do you have what it takes to go it alone and secure the win?

​

**About ProRides**

Here’s your chance to experience what it’s like to ride in the biggest races in the world, thanks to SYSTM’s 4DP platform. We’ve taken the first-person camera footage and power data from a pro cyclist and analyzed it to determine which part of their 4DP® profile each of their efforts corresponds to. But since few of us can put down pro-level watts, we made it so all of the efforts are scaled to your own personal 4DP® profile. That means you get to experience exactly what the pros experience relative to your own abilities. When they sprint, you sprint. When they attack, you attack. When they sit up, you get to take it (relatively) easy. It's the most immersive, realistic race simulation out there.

​

[Here's some more information on how to create the most immersive ProRides experience.](https://wahoosystm.com/HelpCenterProRides)

​

**Featured Footage: **Velon

prospects.name: Giro d'Italia 1
prospects.description:
**Featured Rider:** Attila Valter

**Event:** Giro d'Italia

**Mission:** It's the final stage of your first Grand Tour. For the past three weeks, you've battled your way across Italy. What better way to finish than leaving it all on the road in a final, short time trial. It's you against the clock in the race of truth.

​

**About ProRides**

If you’ve ever dreamed of being a professional cyclist, now’s your chance. The SYSTM ProRide series allows you to experience what it’s like to be in the biggest bike races in the world, thanks to the SYSTM 4DP® platform. We’ve taken the first-person camera footage and power data from a pro cyclist and analyzed it to determine which part of their 4DP® profile each of their efforts corresponds to. But since few of us can put down pro-level watts, we made it so all of the efforts are scaled to your own personal 4DP® profile. That means you get to experience exactly what the pros experience relative to your own abilities. When they sprint, you sprint. When they attack, you attack. When they sit up, you get to take it (relatively) easy. It's the most immersive, realistic race simulation out there.

​

[Here's some more information on how to create the most immersive ProRides experience.](https://wahoosystm.com/HelpCenterProRides)

​

**Featured Footage: **Velon

prospects.name: Race Simulation Skills - CX
prospects.description:
This skills session is designed to develop skills for a variety of challenging course conditions and mimic scenarios you will encounter on race day. The skills practiced here are done at race pace so you can focus on proper execution while under pressure. To properly complete this ride you will need to find a field with the following features and bring along some equipment:  
  
- A set of stairs, ideally with enough area at the top to practice re-mounting your bike.  
- A flat, open area to practice Figure 8s. Use water bottles or cones to mark the corners.  
- A hill to practice off-camber riding.  
- Barriers about shin high, which can be made from PVC pipe or improvised using your imagination (and a few water bottles).  
- BONUS: an area with sand or deep and loose dirt.  
  
Here’s how to tackle this session:  
  
Warm-up for 10-15 minutes Z1/Z2 spinning, include two 3-5 second hard accelerations.  
  
Hole Shot + Stairs. Complete 2 sets:  
Simulate your race start by lining up 300-400m away from the stairs, in your starting gear and with one foot unclipped.  
Countdown from 10 and you’re OFF! Clip in and complete an all out 15 second effort.  
Work on shifting up smoothly during the effort as you would in a race.  
Continue the effort around Z3/Z4 effort for 60 seconds while riding towards the base of the stairs.  
Dismount and run up the stairs and remount at the top.  
Between the first and second set, do 50-100m of Field Running.  
  
Barriers. Complete 4-6 sets:  
Set up some barriers (you can make a portable set from PVC pipe, or you can use some water bottles and your imagination).  
Starting about 100m out from your barriers, speed towards the barriers at race pace.  
The challenge is to focus on the timing of your dismount and remount and to keep you leg speed high between the barriers in order to maintain the most momentum.  
  
Figure 8s. Complete 5-10 minutes:  
For more info on Figure 8s read “Tips for Figure 8s”.  
Set up 2 bottles about 30m apart and practice your Figure 8s.  
To simulate a race scenario, drive your first 3-4 pedal strokes super hard coming out of each “turn”.  
Alternate seated efforts and standing efforts and experiment with your gearing to find the best fit for your desired cadence and power.  
  
Sand Pit. Complete 5-10 minutes:  
If you also have access to a sand pit then finish with 4-6 efforts through the sand. See “Tips For Sand” to master this skill.  
Finish with 5-10 minutes of easy spinning to cool down.  
  
**Warm-Up **8 minutes @ RPE 3 -- 55% of FTP -- HR <70%

prospects.name: Trails: Sending It 2.5
prospects.description:
**What?'**

A trail ride at a moderate pace, with the inevitable surge in power to tackle a short hill or technical section at race pace. Find a local or favorite trail of yours that’s not too hilly.

​

**Why?**

Focus on targeting your weaknesses during this trail session in order to improve them come race day.

​

**How?**

This is an unstructured ride - start easy to warmup, then let the trail do the thinking today. If you feel good and want to push the pace, go for it! If you find a section that you struggle to hit cleanly, repeat it a few times until you feel comfortable with it. Don’t feel the need to practice every section you struggle with, but use today's ride as an opportunity to practice your skills at race pace!

Keep the effort below 110% of FTP but spend the bulk of the ride at 75-85% of FTP.

​

Make sure to warm up well before hitting race pace and cool down afterwards.

prospects.name: Bavaria: Fischen
prospects.description:
Meandering along the scenic River Iller, it’s time to break out your gravel bike for a classic cadence build and hold session. We’ll kick off with 5 x 30-second cadence builds, allowing for 2 minutes of recovery between each, before moving on to 5 x 60-second cadence holds, again with 2 minutes recovery.

While this session may be short, it’s a key part of your weekly plan, designed to keep you efficient and in top form, even when the cadence ramps up. Stay smooth and steady—and remember, “no bobbing!”

​

**Cadence Builds:** The name of the game here is absolute peak cadence, not peak power. To achieve this, you need to be in a small gear and have very light resistance. Starting at 90-RPM, steadily increase your cadence until you reach your absolute max with about 5-seconds left, and hold that to the end. Your limiting factor on these efforts needs to be leg speed. If resistance/power output is your limiting factor, try starting in an easier gear, or shift into an easier gear 15-seconds in. Bouncing in the saddle is okay for this drill.

​

**Cadence Holds**: These efforts require you to maintain the highest cadence you can without starting to bounce in the saddle. For some of you that will be 100-RPM, for others, it will be 150-RPM. The key is to settle into YOUR peak sustainable cadence. Like the Builds, the goal here is not high power, so these efforts are limited to 90% of FTP. Do not be surprised if your heart rate is well into Zone 4 by the time you hit the last few holds.


To properly execute this session, your effort between drills needs to be low. With limited recovery time between these maximal Neuromuscular Efforts, riding above Zone 1 between efforts will only reduce your ability to max out your cadence. While the power targets between are Zone 1, do not be surprised if your heart rate does not drop below Zone 2 after the first couple builds.

​

[**Route on Strava**](https://www.strava.com/activities/9885886076)

​

_Your Host: There are few people who know the mountains and roads of Europe better than Wahoo Ambassador Michael Cotty. As founder of The Col Collective, Mike has made a career out of riding, filming, and telling the story of epic rides and mountains across the continent. As your On Location co-creator and host, Mike's engaging character, curious mind, and friendly nature will have you cueing up your next ride with him before you've even finished the cool-down._

prospects.name: Skill Building - CX
prospects.description:
This skills session is designed to mimic a variety of challenging course conditions and scenarios you will encounter on race day. The skills practiced here are done below race pace so you can focus on proper execution. To properly complete this ride you will need to find a field with the following features and bring along some equipment:  
  
A set of stairs, ideally with enough area at the top to practice re-mounting your bike.  
A flat, open area to practice Figure 8s. Use water bottles or cones to mark the corners.  
A hill to practice off-camber riding.  
Barriers about shin high, which can be made from PVC pipe or improvised using your imagination (and a few water bottles).  
  
Here’s how to tackle this session:  
  
Warm-up for 10-15 minutes Z1/Z2 spinning, include 2 x 1 minute Z3 efforts to warm up.  
  
Stairs. Complete 3-4 sets:  
Approach the stairs at a decent speed (but don’t go over a Z3 effort).  
Dismount and focus on the technique needed to maintain your momentum up the stairs. Experiment with both the timing of your dismount and how you hold your bike while running up the stairs. You may wish to sling it over your shoulder or pick it up by the top tube and handlebars.  
At the top remount as smoothly as possible while trying to maintain your forward momentum.  
  
Figure 8s. Complete 5-10 minutes:  
For more info on Figure 8s read “Tips for Figure 8s”.  
Set up two bottles or cones roughly 20m apart and practice your Figure 8s.  
Focus on maintaining your speed, and try to avoid accelerating or surging out of the “turns”.  
If you’re feeling frisky you can break up the Figure 8s with 50-75m Field Runs every couple minutes.  
  
Barriers. Complete 4-8 sets:  
Next, set up some barriers (you can make a portable set from PVC pipe, or you can use some water bottles and your imagination).  
Hit your barrer section at a decent speed (again trying to avoid going over Z3).  
Practice and perfect the timing of your dismount and remount. The key here is keeping your leg speed quick and nimble between the barriers!  
  
Off-Camber Riding. Complete 5-10 minutes:  
Ride to the top of the hill and then ride along the length of the crest. Try to hold a straight line while not gaining or losing elevation.  
Turn around and ride it in the opposite direction.  
As your off-camber skills develop you can try riding faster and faster to see where your limit is, and sometimes that means going over it! Be safe, but remember that you won’t know what you can and can’t do until you try!  
  
Finish with 5-10 minutes of easy spinning to cool down.  
  
**Warm-Up  
**8 minutes @ RPE 3 -- 55% of FTP -- HR <70%  
1 minutes @ RPE 4.5 -- 75% of FTP -- HR <75%  
1 minute @ RPE 3.5 -- 65% of FTP -- HR <75%  
1 minute @ RPE 4.5 -- 75% of FTP -- HR < 80%  
4 minutes @ RPE 3 -- 55% of FTP -- HR <75%  
  
**Main Effort  
**Number of Sets: 4  
Rest Between Sets: 2 minutes  
Interval Repeats per Set: 1  
**Interval  
**8 minutes @ RPE 3 -- 55% of FTP -- HR <70% focusing on assigned skill  
2 minutes @ RPE 2 -- 45% of FTP -- HR <70%  
  
**Extra Volume  
**N/A  
  
**Cool Down  
**5 minutes @ RPE 1.5 -- 45% of FTP -- HR <70%

prospects.name: Do As You're Told
prospects.description:
The little voice in your head is telling you to stop. The screams from your legs are nearly deafening. But you hear none of it. You're following orders to ATTACK.

​

This is the story of two men in a car—your team directors—who guide you to GLORY. Ignore them at your own risk: They will not tolerate insubordination.

​

In this session, you'll tackle two sets of 11 intervals each. The first set has high-intensity efforts with matching recoveries. This pushes your body's ability to recover right to the limit -- just what you need to improve Anaerobic Capacity (AC). The shorter, super-high intensity efforts also help with your Neuromuscular Power (NM). The second set features inverse intervals with opposite efforts and recoveries. This really depletes your body's AC, so you need to rely on your aerobic system. This helps develop your Maximal Aerobic Power.

prospects.name: Bavaria: Burgberg
prospects.description:
This may be a short workout, but it packs a serious punch—so lace up those gloves and get ready for 22 powerful 10-second seated sprints!

After a gentle warm-up leaving the picturesque village of Sulzberg, we’ll dive straight into our first block: 8 x 10-second high-cadence seated sprints with 50 seconds of recovery.

As the road naturally levels out, we’ll catch our breath before hitting the core of the workout—9 x 10-second low-cadence seated sprints with the same 50-second recovery, focusing on maintaining rock-solid form.

To close things out, we’ll return to the high-cadence style for a final round of 5 x 10-second sprints. This session is designed to sharpen muscle activation and improve recovery after intense efforts.

Finish strong, and I’ll see you in Burgberg!

​

With short near-maximal sprint efforts like these, you’ll recruit all of the muscle fibers in your legs. While cadence builds force your muscles to contract and relax as quickly as possible, this session forces your muscles to contract with maximal power. Just like cadence builds, this session becomes one of the best ways to train your neuromuscular system.

Even if your target event does not require you to complete maximal sprints, there is a substantial trickle-down efficiency effect to the longer-duration power efforts when you train your neuromuscular system.

​

[**Route on Strava**](https://www.strava.com/activities/9866624296)

​

_Your Host: There are few people who know the mountains and roads of Europe better than Wahoo Ambassador Michael Cotty. As founder of The Col Collective, Mike has made a career out of riding, filming, and telling the story of epic rides and mountains across the continent. As your On Location co-creator and host, Mike's engaging character, curious mind, and friendly nature will have you cueing up your next ride with him before you've even finished the cool-down._

prospects.name: Gran Canaria: Serenity
prospects.description:
Starting at the islands iconic rainbow rocks at Los Azulejos de Veneguera in this session we tackle one of the most stunning climbs on the whole island, known locally as “Serenity”. We’ll be breaking this 10km climb down into three distinct sections, kicking off with a block of 6 x 50 second high tempo efforts with a 10 second burst out of the saddle before taking a swift breather before getting back on it. As we climb through the pine forest we’ll switch things up a touch, alternating between low and high cadence for 30 seconds at a time for around 7 minutes. We’ll then revert back to our 50 second high tempo with 10 second burst out of the saddle efforts before we build up our effort to the summit. This is going to be a challenging workout so make sure you’re ready and whatever you do don’t forget to take a moment to look at the views!!

​

This workout combines multiple different interval types that focus on improving threshold power via over-under style efforts along with low cadence work for your muscular endurance. The first and last climbs also fire up your whole energy systems with some sprints to the summit.

​

prospects.name: Tempo/Threshold/MAP: 6 x 3-2-1
prospects.description:
This should be a key session for anyone who wants to improve their FTP, oxygen utilization efficiency, and the ability to recover quickly between hard efforts. The efforts themselves aren't outrageous, but the short recovery periods and the demand to continue repeating them make this a challenging session. The main set of the workout contains six sets of:

- 3 minutes at 90% LT power + 1 minute of recovery
- 2 minutes at 100% LT power + 1 minute recovery
- 1 minute at 110% LT power + 1 minute recovery with no additional rest before repeating the set.

This is a tough session so focus on recovery after this workout. Stretching and/or self massaging, replacing your fluids, and eating a meal containing carbohydrates and protein will all help to rebuild the muscles and grow stronger!

​

prospects.name: Tempo Build: 1 x 60
prospects.description:
Tempo sessions are always a great time to work on pace control, especially Tempo efforts longer than 30 minutes. We are taking that pacing demand a bit further in this session by forcing you to slightly increase your effort as time goes on. This is referred to as a "Negative-Split", meaning the second half is faster (or you hold a higher power) than the first half.

​

While you might question the benefit of doing "easier" tempo efforts, the truth is when riding between 80% and 100% of FTP your body processes oxygen and metabolites at nearly the same rate. Holding a higher power will give you a higher single day training stimulus, but looking at the big picture that can have its drawbacks. Mainly the fatigue those harder sessions cause, which requires easier workouts the days before and after. Sticking to the Tempo targets gets you nearly the same training stimulus while allowing you to hit harder sessions the rest of the week.

​

This session contains a single 60-minute tempo effort, broken into three 20-minute segments. You will spend the first 20-minutes at 80% of FTP, the next 20 at 84%, and the final 20 at 87%. By the time you hit the last 10-minutes of this effort, that 87% will feel much harder than it should. Another way of thinking about this one, if you were to reverse the order, and start at 87%, what you would likely find is that your RPE stays fairly consistent for the entire effort, even though the power targets are dropping.

​

Overheating, not drinking enough, being under-fueled and mental fatigue will all play a factor in how you feel in that final block. They will also impact your heart rate. While these power targets are usually associated with Zone 3 heart rate, many people will see their heart rate climb into low Z4 if they are not hydrating properly, or have inadequate cooling. This can be a great session to act as a "wake up call" on any poor training habits you might have so take note and aim to address those issues during your next workout.

​

**Warm Up**

30 minutes @ RPE 2.5 -- 55% of FTP -- HR <70%

1 minute @ RPE 7 -- 95% of FTP -- HR <100%

1 minute @ RPE 7.5 -- 100% of FTP -- HR <100%

1 minute @ RPE 8 -- 105% of FTP -- HR <100%

7 minutes @ RPE 2.5 -- 55% of FTP -- HR <70%

​

**Main Effort**

**Interval**

​

**Extra Volume**

45 minutes @ RPE 3 -- 60% of FTP -- HR <70%

​

**Cool Down**

5 minutes @ RPE 2 -- 50% of FTP -- HR <70%

prospects.name: 14 Vise Grips
prospects.description:
You can never have too many tools in the shed. After years of lobbying, we finally convinced Grunter von Agony to share his favorite set of implements with us: the fabled _14 Vise Grips_. Taken individually, each of the 14 intervals might appear tame, incapable of inflicting a significant squeeze. But when expertly applied in the correct order, they apply just the right kind of pressure to turn a Couchlandrian into a Sufferlandrian, just like turning coal into diamonds.

​

While the duration of each Vise Grip varies (from 30 seconds to 2 minutes), the power targets and recovery durations between them remain constant. The first 30-second interval should feel like a Sunday stroll in the park, but by the end of the first 2-minute Vise Grip, you'll be cursing Grunter's name. As the intervals get shorter, time will appear to stretch. That final 30-second effort will feel like an eternity. When you roll up to the second set, you'll know what you're in for, so just put your head down and prepare yourself to crush or be crushed.

​

Once you make it through all 14 Vise Grips, you will have been north of your Maximal Aerobic Power (MAP) for a total of 16 minutes. Changing the duration of the efforts (while keeping the same recovery) stresses your Anaerobic Capacity (AC) in a more dynamic way than, say, a more straightforward on/off session like _Half is Easy_. Since the longer efforts have the same recovery duration as the shorter ones, you will eventually deplete your AC, forcing your body to rely on your MAP to hit the required power targets. As the intervals get shorter in the second half of each set, you'll find that you have just enough left in the tank to complete the next effort.

​

Ultimately this workout combines the advantages of shorter, higher-power intervals with longer recovery (great for building muscular strength) with the advantages of longer, higher-power intervals with inadequate recovery (great for driving up your MAP and improving your AC).

prospects.name: Costa Blanca: Coll de Rates
prospects.description:
This session is all about building your VO₂ Max power with a focus on pacing. You’ll start with a flat warm-up to get the body ready before diving into a progressive series of ramping intervals. Each interval gets shorter but more intense, pushing your cardiovascular system while keeping your legs working under control. The aim is to help you finish strong — not fade — by learning how to pace properly through effort buildup.

​

Set on the steady slopes of Coll de Rates, the consistent gradient supports rhythm and control, allowing you to focus on cadence, breathing, and technique as you go deeper into the red. The final threshold block adds bonus training stimulus and flushes the legs under fatigue. This is a session that builds smarter, stronger climbers — from both a physical and mental standpoint.

​

prospects.name: The Model
prospects.description:
They say that beauty is in the eye of the beholder. And through the bleeding eyes of Sufferlandrians, what could possibly be more beautiful than the sharp, saw-tooth profile of the workout you see before you? Full of gorgeous, shapely, shimmering blocks of yellow Maximal Aerobic Power (MAP) efforts interspersed with mercifully brief and slightly inadequate recoveries, it's a real stunner.

​

But you know what's even better looking than this alluring workout? You (after you've completed the workout, that is). Originally designed by our Head of Sports Science, Neal Henderson, for his professional athletes, The Model is a beautiful portrait of MAP brutality. It's one of those sessions that you think you can't finish, but always somehow do. It will leave you breathless, feeling all tingly, a bit confused and lying in a blubbering heap. It's a look. It will also deliver a nice boost to your fitness that always looks and feels good.

​

A true love letter to the beauty of professional cycling, The Model features a banging soundtrack and thrilling footage from both the men's and women's pelotons. With its eclectic design, effects, and graphics, you'll find yourself unable to tear your eyes away from the action on screen (assuming you can lift them from your stem).

prospects.name: Bavaria: Fischen
prospects.description:
Meandering along the scenic River Iller, it’s time to break out your gravel bike for a classic cadence build and hold session. We’ll kick off with 5 x 30-second cadence builds, allowing for 2 minutes of recovery between each, before moving on to 5 x 60-second cadence holds, again with 2 minutes recovery.

While this session may be short, it’s a key part of your weekly plan, designed to keep you efficient and in top form, even when the cadence ramps up. Stay smooth and steady—and remember, “no bobbing!”

​

**Cadence Builds:** The name of the game here is absolute peak cadence, not peak power. To achieve this, you need to be in a small gear and have very light resistance. Starting at 90-RPM, steadily increase your cadence until you reach your absolute max with about 5-seconds left, and hold that to the end. Your limiting factor on these efforts needs to be leg speed. If resistance/power output is your limiting factor, try starting in an easier gear, or shift into an easier gear 15-seconds in. Bouncing in the saddle is okay for this drill.

​

**Cadence Holds**: These efforts require you to maintain the highest cadence you can without starting to bounce in the saddle. For some of you that will be 100-RPM, for others, it will be 150-RPM. The key is to settle into YOUR peak sustainable cadence. Like the Builds, the goal here is not high power, so these efforts are limited to 90% of FTP. Do not be surprised if your heart rate is well into Zone 4 by the time you hit the last few holds.


To properly execute this session, your effort between drills needs to be low. With limited recovery time between these maximal Neuromuscular Efforts, riding above Zone 1 between efforts will only reduce your ability to max out your cadence. While the power targets between are Zone 1, do not be surprised if your heart rate does not drop below Zone 2 after the first couple builds.

​

[**Route on Strava**](https://www.strava.com/activities/9885886076)

​

_Your Host: There are few people who know the mountains and roads of Europe better than Wahoo Ambassador Michael Cotty. As founder of The Col Collective, Mike has made a career out of riding, filming, and telling the story of epic rides and mountains across the continent. As your On Location co-creator and host, Mike's engaging character, curious mind, and friendly nature will have you cueing up your next ride with him before you've even finished the cool-down._

prospects.name: Micro Intervals/Tempo: 2 x 12 Plus 1 x 20
prospects.description:
These two mini Pyramids of Power might remind you of The Shovel... This one, however is a little less focused on Anaerobic Capacity and a little more on muscle endurance, due to that big blue block in the middle. The first pyramid will begin to fatigue your muscles and tax your AC before you face 20 minutes at tempo. With both of those efforts under your belt, the second pyramid will drain the rest of your AC and ask your aerobic system to pick up the slack. This might even feel similar to a mountain bike or cyclocross race effort- you take it out hard, jockeying for the hole shot or a front pack position before getting into the technical elements. Then you settle into a sustainable effort for a short while, maybe working with a couple others before battling it out for your final finishing position.

​

prospects.name: Trails: Cruising 3
prospects.description:
**What?** 

A trail ride at a cruisy pace.

​

**Why?** 

Variety is the spice of life and it’s also the best way to accomplish a few goals simultaneously. Focus on targeting your weaknesses during this trail session in order to improve them come race day.

​

**How?** 

This is an unstructured ride - let the trail do the thinking today. If you find a section that you struggle to hit cleanly, repeat that section a few times until you feel comfortable with it. Don’t feel the need to practice every section you struggle with on a single ride, you can always come back another day! Keep the effort below 85% of FTP at all times and spend the bulk of the ride around 60% of FTP.

​

Make sure to warm up well and cool down afterwards.

prospects.name: The Frozen Road
prospects.description:
🎬 Film (2017): From the creator: "Self-shot and edited whilst cycling around the world, this film charts a winter journey into the Canadian Arctic as I completed my bike ride up the American continent. Compelled by Jack London’s assertion, that ‘any man who is a man can travel alone,' I sought an adventure of perfect solitude. Yet, as I came to realize, the harsh truths of traveling in such a formidable environment were a long way from the romantic images I’d held of this land. _The Frozen Road_’ is an honest reflection on my solo trip; of the wonder, terror and frustration I experienced when riding through the unforgiving emptiness of one of the world’s ‘last great wildernesses."

​

🚴 Workout: The workout accompanying this film is a recovery session. It's a very low-intensity ride, with your power remaining at or below 50% of FTP (an RPE less than 2.5 on a scale from 1 to 10) and your heart rate in Zone 1. The intensity and cadence targets will vary throughout this session to keep it interesting, but not so much that it distracts you from the story.

​

[Here's how to turn off on-screen graphics for the best viewing experience.](https://wahoosystm.com/HelpCenterInspiration)

prospects.name: Skill Building - CX
prospects.description:
This skills session is designed to mimic a variety of challenging course conditions and scenarios you will encounter on race day. The skills practiced here are done below race pace so you can focus on proper execution. To properly complete this ride you will need to find a field with the following features and bring along some equipment:  
  
A set of stairs, ideally with enough area at the top to practice re-mounting your bike.  
A flat, open area to practice Figure 8s. Use water bottles or cones to mark the corners.  
A hill to practice off-camber riding.  
Barriers about shin high, which can be made from PVC pipe or improvised using your imagination (and a few water bottles).  
  
Here’s how to tackle this session:  
  
Warm-up for 10-15 minutes Z1/Z2 spinning, include 2 x 1 minute Z3 efforts to warm up.  
  
Stairs. Complete 3-4 sets:  
Approach the stairs at a decent speed (but don’t go over a Z3 effort).  
Dismount and focus on the technique needed to maintain your momentum up the stairs. Experiment with both the timing of your dismount and how you hold your bike while running up the stairs. You may wish to sling it over your shoulder or pick it up by the top tube and handlebars.  
At the top remount as smoothly as possible while trying to maintain your forward momentum.  
  
Figure 8s. Complete 5-10 minutes:  
For more info on Figure 8s read “Tips for Figure 8s”.  
Set up two bottles or cones roughly 20m apart and practice your Figure 8s.  
Focus on maintaining your speed, and try to avoid accelerating or surging out of the “turns”.  
If you’re feeling frisky you can break up the Figure 8s with 50-75m Field Runs every couple minutes.  
  
Barriers. Complete 4-8 sets:  
Next, set up some barriers (you can make a portable set from PVC pipe, or you can use some water bottles and your imagination).  
Hit your barrer section at a decent speed (again trying to avoid going over Z3).  
Practice and perfect the timing of your dismount and remount. The key here is keeping your leg speed quick and nimble between the barriers!  
  
Off-Camber Riding. Complete 5-10 minutes:  
Ride to the top of the hill and then ride along the length of the crest. Try to hold a straight line while not gaining or losing elevation.  
Turn around and ride it in the opposite direction.  
As your off-camber skills develop you can try riding faster and faster to see where your limit is, and sometimes that means going over it! Be safe, but remember that you won’t know what you can and can’t do until you try!  
  
Finish with 5-10 minutes of easy spinning to cool down.  
  
**Warm-Up  
**8 minutes @ RPE 3 -- 55% of FTP -- HR <70%  
1 minutes @ RPE 4.5 -- 75% of FTP -- HR <75%  
1 minute @ RPE 3.5 -- 65% of FTP -- HR <75%  
1 minute @ RPE 4.5 -- 75% of FTP -- HR < 80%  
4 minutes @ RPE 3 -- 55% of FTP -- HR <75%  
  
**Main Effort  
**Number of Sets: 4  
Rest Between Sets: 2 minutes  
Interval Repeats per Set: 1  
**Interval  
**8 minutes @ RPE 3 -- 55% of FTP -- HR <70% focusing on assigned skill  
2 minutes @ RPE 2 -- 45% of FTP -- HR <70%  
  
**Extra Volume  
**N/A  
  
**Cool Down  
**5 minutes @ RPE 1.5 -- 45% of FTP -- HR <70%

prospects.name: Costa Blanca: Puerto de la Vall de Ebo (Recharger Ride)
prospects.description:
This is an active recovery ride built with purpose. Low-intensity endurance work is paired with brief high-cadence neuromuscular activations to keep the nervous system awake without creating new fatigue. You’ll stay well below threshold throughout, allowing your body to absorb previous hard sessions and prepare for what’s ahead.

​

Set on the peaceful roads leading to the summit of Port de la Vall d’Ebo, this ride promotes circulation, technique, and mental reset. It’s ideal after race days or big training blocks — a smart session that helps you recover better, so you can train harder tomorrow. No ego, no watts chasing — just intentional recovery done right.

​

[**Wahoo Route**](https://www.strava.com/activities/13996505846)

​

_Your Host: There are few people who know the mountains and roads of Europe better than Wahoo Ambassador Michael Cotty. As founder of The Col Collective, Mike has made a career out of riding, filming, and telling the story of epic rides and mountains across the continent. As your On Location co-creator and host, Mike's engaging character, curious mind, and friendly nature will have you cueing up your next ride with him before you've even finished the cool-down._

prospects.name: Half Monty (Ramp Test)
prospects.description:
**Half Monty: The Easy One.**

​

We recommend this fitness test for:

- Newer riders
- Athletes with limited experience pacing maximal efforts / fitness testing.
- Those who are mid-plan or who just want to get a sense of where their fitness is.

The _Half Monty_ 4DP fitness test is the most accurate and complete ramp test available. While it's not as comprehensive or as accurate as our main fitness test, _Full Frontal_, it's far more approachable and easier to pace for new riders. It also doesn't require any special preparation. You just need to feel relatively fresh.

​

Based on more than a year of research (and after dozens of lab tests and thousands of online tests) and using sophisticated analysis of power and heart rate data, _Half Monty_ is far more accurate and comprehensive than standard ramp tests.

​

It also tells you more about who you are as an athlete. _Half Monty_ provides you with your FTP, Maximal Aerobic Power (MAP), and Cycling Threshold Heart Rate (cTHR), all of which we use to personalize your workout targets.

​

If you're still using the 4DP estimates when you set up your account, _Half Monty_ will also refine your AC and NM estimates (but will not do so if you've done _Full Frontal_ or manually adjusted your estimates). If you want fully accurate AC and NM, as well as your Rider Type, Strengths, Weaknesses, and training plans adjusted to those Strengths and Weaknesses, you'll need to expose yourself to the _Full Frontal_ 4DP fitness test.

​

Ready to climb the ramp? You'll need the following before you start:

- A heart rate monitor if you want the most accurate results. Don't have one? Order one [HERE](https://wahoofitness.com/devices)
- Some kind of power device connected (trainer, power meter, virtual power, etc.)
- Be ready to pay close attention to the instructions in the workout
- Be sure your profile is complete and up-to-date (Profile > About You). Accurate information helps us make our calculations

**LEARN MORE**

Listen to '[Why Fitness Testing Matters](https://the-knowledge-by-wahoo-sports-science.simplecast.com/episodes/testing-testing-1-2-3-why-fitness-testing-matters)' on The Knowledge Podcast by Wahoo Sports Science.

​

[Here's some more information on how to get the most from your fitness test.](https://wahoosystm.com/HelpCenterFitnessAssessment)

prospects.name: XC Trails: Hour Cruise
prospects.description:
**What?** 

A trail ride at a cruisy pace.

​

**Why?** 

Variety is the spice of life and it’s also the best way to accomplish a few goals simultaneously. Focus on targeting your weaknesses during this trail session in order to improve them come race day.

​

**How?** 

This is an unstructured ride - let the trail do the thinking today. If you find a section that you struggle to hit cleanly, repeat that section a few times until you feel comfortable with it. Don’t feel the need to practice every section you struggle with on a single ride, you can always come back another day! Keep the effort below 85% of FTP and spend the bulk of the ride around 60% of FTP.

prospects.name: Cash Register
prospects.description:
Over/under intervals, where you alternate going just below and just above threshold, are the foundation of many classic workouts. Cash Register is an adaptation of that idea and comes in the format of a sprint/settle/surge session consisting of 4 intervals that get a little shorter (but not easier) each round.

​

Each interval kicks off with a sprint effort that targets your Neuromuscular (NM) power. Then you settle into a controlled, below-FTP effort that will accelerate the rate at which you can clear lactate from your muscles. You'll finish each effort off with a big surge based on your Anaerobic Capacity (AC). In just 30 minutes, you'll be doing efforts targeting your sprint power, FTP, and AC for an exceptionally well-rounded workout.

​

Support the Wahooligan Tour by [donating to the Davis Phinney Foundation](https://secure2.convio.net/dpf/site/TR?pg=pfind&fr_id=1391) and their programs to help people living with Parkinsons.

prospects.name: P. Gaimon 3: Short KOM Training Session
prospects.description:
As part of his ‘Worst Retirement Ever,’ Phil made a name for himself by sniping Strava KOMs around the world. But if you’re going to travel around globe stealing crowns from some of the world’s fastest climbers, you need to bring your A-game.

​

In this short, 35-minute workout, Phil takes you through a warm-up on the famous Pacific Coast Highway before climbing into two short, maximal efforts on the way up Dekker Canyon. You’ll be in the hurt box, but be sure to pay attention as Phil drops his top tips for KOM / QOM segment success.

​

In between efforts, Phil keeps you entertained with stories about his Cookie Fondo, life in LA, a tour of his garage, a face lick from his dog and his personal recommendation for the best cold-pressed juice in town.

​

_Do this on: Day 3 of the 5-day plan._

prospects.name: Bavaria: Burgberg
prospects.description:
This may be a short workout, but it packs a serious punch—so lace up those gloves and get ready for 22 powerful 10-second seated sprints!

After a gentle warm-up leaving the picturesque village of Sulzberg, we’ll dive straight into our first block: 8 x 10-second high-cadence seated sprints with 50 seconds of recovery.

As the road naturally levels out, we’ll catch our breath before hitting the core of the workout—9 x 10-second low-cadence seated sprints with the same 50-second recovery, focusing on maintaining rock-solid form.

To close things out, we’ll return to the high-cadence style for a final round of 5 x 10-second sprints. This session is designed to sharpen muscle activation and improve recovery after intense efforts.

Finish strong, and I’ll see you in Burgberg!

​

With short near-maximal sprint efforts like these, you’ll recruit all of the muscle fibers in your legs. While cadence builds force your muscles to contract and relax as quickly as possible, this session forces your muscles to contract with maximal power. Just like cadence builds, this session becomes one of the best ways to train your neuromuscular system.

Even if your target event does not require you to complete maximal sprints, there is a substantial trickle-down efficiency effect to the longer-duration power efforts when you train your neuromuscular system.

​

[**Route on Strava**](https://www.strava.com/activities/9866624296)

​

_Your Host: There are few people who know the mountains and roads of Europe better than Wahoo Ambassador Michael Cotty. As founder of The Col Collective, Mike has made a career out of riding, filming, and telling the story of epic rides and mountains across the continent. As your On Location co-creator and host, Mike's engaging character, curious mind, and friendly nature will have you cueing up your next ride with him before you've even finished the cool-down._

prospects.name: Rolling Trail Run 30 mins
prospects.description:
If possible, choose a trail that is rolling terrain or mostly flat in order to keep the effort low-moderate.

​

For help understanding your run workout and calculating your pace zones, please see [this article](https://wahoosystm.com/RunningSessionFAQ).

Learn how to perform your [**Running Drills**](https://support.wahoofitness.com/hc/en-us/articles/4404080091922-Running-Drills) here.

prospects.name: Across the Mountains
prospects.description:
🎬 Film (2020): _Across the Mountains_ follows legendary cyclist Michael Cotty through two different adventures. The first, _Les Alpes_, is the story of Mike's non-stop ride from Evian-Les-Bains to Nice across the heart of the Alps: a journey of 677km with 17 mountain passes and more than 16,000 meters of climbing. The second, _The Road to Mont Blanc_, sees Mike tackle a 1,000 km non-stop journey across 21 mountains in the Dolomites, Eastern and Swiss Alps before finishing at Mont Blanc. Featuring never-before-seen footage and exclusive commentary by Mike Cotty himself.

​

🚴 Workout: The workout accompanying this film is a recovery session. Intensity is low, with power remaining at or below 50% of FTP (2.5 on a scale from 1 to 10) with heart rate targets entirely in Zone 1. The intensity and cadence targets will vary throughout this session to keep it interesting, but not so much that it distracts you from the story.

​

[Here's how to turn off on-screen graphics for the best viewing experience.](https://wahoosystm.com/HelpCenterInspiration)

​
prospects.notes: After Trail Run or later in the day.

prospects.name: Cadence Builds
prospects.description:
One of the best sessions for neuromuscular training, this drill asks you to progressively build from a cadence of 90 RPM to your MAX over 30 seconds, recover, and repeat several times. Cadence builds improve how you recruit your leg, gluteal, and core muscles throughout your pedal stroke by progressing to your maximal cadence. By reaching your highest cadence possible, you are training the 'on/off' switch in each muscle group to not only work faster but to have less overlap with your other muscle groups. This session trains your hamstring muscles to 'turn off' when your quads 'turn on' and vice-versa, resulting in a more efficient pedal stroke at both high and low cadences.

​

**LEARN MORE**

Listen to The Knowledge podcast, by Wahoo Sports Science - The Benefits of High Cadence Training: [https://wahoosystm.com/BenefitsofHighCadence](https://wahoosystm.com/BenefitsofHighCadence)

prospects.name: Openers
prospects.description:
Whether you have power testing, a group ride you want to smash, that event you have been training all winter for, or even just a fun route you want to have a great ride on, this is the perfect session to do the day before. The key to this session is just enough time right around threshold, with sufficient recovery between efforts and a handful of sprints to prime all of your systems for tomorrow's event.

​

**Warm-Up**

4 minutes @ RPE 2 -- 45% of FTP -- HR <65%

1 minutes @ RPE 3 -- 55% of FTP -- HR <70%

1 minute @ RPE 4 -- 65% of FTP -- HR <80%

1 minute @ RPE 5 -- 75% of FTP -- HR <85%

30 seconds @ RPE 2 -- 45% of FTP -- HR <75%

30 seconds @ RPE 9 -- 90-95% of AC (130-190% of FTP)

4 minutes @ RPE 2 -- 45% of FTP -- HR <70%

​

**Main Effort**

Number of sets: 3, all unique

Rest Between Sets: 8 minutes @ RPE 2 -- 45% of FTP -- HR <75%

**Set 1**

Interval Repeats per set: 1

Interval: Effort: 3 minutes at @ RPE 7 -- 90% of FTP --HR <95%

**Set 2**

Interval Repeats per set: 1

Interval: Effort: 2 minutes @ RPE 7.5 -- 100% of FTP -- HR <100%

**Set 3**

Interval Repeats per set: 3

Interval: Effort: 30 seconds @ RPE 9 -- 95% of MAP (110-130% of FTP)

Recovery: 90 seconds @ RPE 2 -- 45% of FTP -- HR <75%

​

**Extra Volume**

N/A

​

**Cool Down**

6 minutes @ RPE 1.5 -- <45% of FTP

prospects.name: Blender
prospects.description:
A smorgasbord of Suffering, this session has it all. Originally created in Coach Sir Neal Henderson's Penn State dorm room in 1992, it's his weapon of choice for bringing the pain (shakes).

​

What's in the Blender? First, a variety of longer efforts build sustained power while also making sure you're sufficiently fatigued. This initial beatdown is necessary to ensure you get the maximum benefit from _Blender_'s infamous 'Pain Shakes.' Three sets of these little devils help you develop a supernatural ability to recover from big efforts. The bonus is that you also beef up your ability to produce high-end power, building Anaerobic Capacity and Maximal Aerobic Power simultaneously.

​

The threshold efforts at the end are the bitter cherry on the sundae, improving your body's ability to produce aerobic power and helping make sure your FTP will get the same boost as your AC and MAP. A rising tide of lactic acid raises all boats. Oh, and clocking in at one hour and 40 minutes, Blender will also help whip your endurance into a frenzy.

prospects.name: Trails: Cruising 2
prospects.description:

A trail ride at a cruisy pace.

​

**Why?**

Variety is the spice of life and it’s also the best way to accomplish a few goals simultaneously. Focus on targeting your weaknesses during this trail session in order to improve them come race day.

​

This is an unstructured ride - let the trail do the thinking today. If you find a section that you struggle to hit cleanly, repeat that section a few times until you feel comfortable with it. Don’t feel the need to practice every section you struggle with on a single ride, you can always come back another day! Keep the effort below 85% of FTP at all times and spend the bulk of the ride around 60% of FTP.

Make sure to warm up well and cool down afterwards.

prospects.name: Aerobic Run 30
prospects.description:
For help understanding your run workout and calculating your pace zones, please see [this article](https://wahoosystm.com/RunningSessionFAQ).

Learn how to perform your [**Running Drills**](https://support.wahoofitness.com/hc/en-us/articles/4404080091922-Running-Drills) here.

NA

Number of Sets: 1

prospects.name: Standing Starts
prospects.description:
_Standing Starts_ closely simulates a lifting session on the bike because it requires the engagement of your core, upper body, and lower body. It trains your ability to generate force through the pedals by ensuring you recruit ALL of your muscles to get those cranks turning. No matter your preferred discipline, these efforts are key to teaching your body to recruit all of the muscle fibers in your legs.

​

All of the benefits in this session come from hitting these 20-second efforts as hard as you possibly can. To do that, you need full recovery between each sprint, and you need to respect that recovery. These efforts should see you start at super low RPMs with very high torque. As you start and increase the effort, your cadence will naturally increase. **Your goal is to get your cadence as high as possible by the end of each 20-second effort.** To maximize your muscle recruitment, you want to both push down and pull up on the pedals at the start. Proper core engagement is a must - your legs need a good strong backboard to push against.

​

We understand that not everyone's trainer has the necessary resistance or the required stability to perform this workout as described. If you can't safely stand up, then you can get much of the same benefit by doing these efforts seated. If your trainer can’t handle the rapid change in speed or does not have high enough resistance at a super low cadence, then you can start the efforts at a higher cadence and treat them as “normal” all-out sprints.

prospects.name: Costa Blanca: Puerto de Tudons
prospects.description:
This session is a variation on over-unders, designed to elevate your MAP (maximal aerobic power) while keeping your cardiovascular system under constant strain. You'll alternate between hard MAP intervals and “recoveries” that are still above endurance level — forcing your heart rate and respiration to stay elevated throughout.

​

Set on the consistent, climb-friendly terrain of Port de Tudons, this workout encourages rhythm and control, with a focus on maintaining high cadence to emphasize cardio over muscular strain. The structure builds your ability to sustain high power outputs under stress, improving your breakaway potential and fatigue resistance without requiring extended time at VO₂ Max power.

​

[**Wahoo Route**](https://www.strava.com/activities/14035782507)

​

_Your Host: There are few people who know the mountains and roads of Europe better than Wahoo Ambassador Michael Cotty. As founder of The Col Collective, Mike has made a career out of riding, filming, and telling the story of epic rides and mountains across the continent. As your On Location co-creator and host, Mike's engaging character, curious mind, and friendly nature will have you cueing up your next ride with him before you've even finished the cool-down._

prospects.name: Skill Building - CX
prospects.description:
This skills session is designed to mimic a variety of challenging course conditions and scenarios you will encounter on race day. The skills practiced here are done below race pace so you can focus on proper execution. To properly complete this ride you will need to find a field with the following features and bring along some equipment:  
  
A set of stairs, ideally with enough area at the top to practice re-mounting your bike.  
A flat, open area to practice Figure 8s. Use water bottles or cones to mark the corners.  
A hill to practice off-camber riding.  
Barriers about shin high, which can be made from PVC pipe or improvised using your imagination (and a few water bottles).  
  
Here’s how to tackle this session:  
  
Warm-up for 10-15 minutes Z1/Z2 spinning, include 2 x 1 minute Z3 efforts to warm up.  
  
Stairs. Complete 3-4 sets:  
Approach the stairs at a decent speed (but don’t go over a Z3 effort).  
Dismount and focus on the technique needed to maintain your momentum up the stairs. Experiment with both the timing of your dismount and how you hold your bike while running up the stairs. You may wish to sling it over your shoulder or pick it up by the top tube and handlebars.  
At the top remount as smoothly as possible while trying to maintain your forward momentum.  
  
Figure 8s. Complete 5-10 minutes:  
For more info on Figure 8s read “Tips for Figure 8s”.  
Set up two bottles or cones roughly 20m apart and practice your Figure 8s.  
Focus on maintaining your speed, and try to avoid accelerating or surging out of the “turns”.  
If you’re feeling frisky you can break up the Figure 8s with 50-75m Field Runs every couple minutes.  
  
Barriers. Complete 4-8 sets:  
Next, set up some barriers (you can make a portable set from PVC pipe, or you can use some water bottles and your imagination).  
Hit your barrer section at a decent speed (again trying to avoid going over Z3).  
Practice and perfect the timing of your dismount and remount. The key here is keeping your leg speed quick and nimble between the barriers!  
  
Off-Camber Riding. Complete 5-10 minutes:  
Ride to the top of the hill and then ride along the length of the crest. Try to hold a straight line while not gaining or losing elevation.  
Turn around and ride it in the opposite direction.  
As your off-camber skills develop you can try riding faster and faster to see where your limit is, and sometimes that means going over it! Be safe, but remember that you won’t know what you can and can’t do until you try!  
  
Finish with 5-10 minutes of easy spinning to cool down.  
  
**Warm-Up  
**8 minutes @ RPE 3 -- 55% of FTP -- HR <70%  
1 minutes @ RPE 4.5 -- 75% of FTP -- HR <75%  
1 minute @ RPE 3.5 -- 65% of FTP -- HR <75%  
1 minute @ RPE 4.5 -- 75% of FTP -- HR < 80%  
4 minutes @ RPE 3 -- 55% of FTP -- HR <75%  
  
**Main Effort  
**Number of Sets: 4  
Rest Between Sets: 2 minutes  
Interval Repeats per Set: 1  
**Interval  
**8 minutes @ RPE 3 -- 55% of FTP -- HR <70% focusing on assigned skill  
2 minutes @ RPE 2 -- 45% of FTP -- HR <70%  
  
**Extra Volume  
**N/A  
  
**Cool Down  
**5 minutes @ RPE 1.5 -- 45% of FTP -- HR <70%

prospects.name: Micro Intervals/Tempo: 2 x 12 Plus 1 x 20
prospects.description:
These two mini Pyramids of Power might remind you of The Shovel... This one, however is a little less focused on Anaerobic Capacity and a little more on muscle endurance, due to that big blue block in the middle. The first pyramid will begin to fatigue your muscles and tax your AC before you face 20 minutes at tempo. With both of those efforts under your belt, the second pyramid will drain the rest of your AC and ask your aerobic system to pick up the slack. This might even feel similar to a mountain bike or cyclocross race effort- you take it out hard, jockeying for the hole shot or a front pack position before getting into the technical elements. Then you settle into a sustainable effort for a short while, maybe working with a couple others before battling it out for your final finishing position.

​

**Warm Up**
