prospects.name: Trails: Cruising 3
prospects.description:
**What?** 

A trail ride at a cruisy pace.

​

**Why?** 

Variety is the spice of life and it’s also the best way to accomplish a few goals simultaneously. Focus on targeting your weaknesses during this trail session in order to improve them come race day.

​

**How?** 

This is an unstructured ride - let the trail do the thinking today. If you find a section that you struggle to hit cleanly, repeat that section a few times until you feel comfortable with it. Don’t feel the need to practice every section you struggle with on a single ride, you can always come back another day! Keep the effort below 85% of FTP at all times and spend the bulk of the ride around 60% of FTP.

​

Make sure to warm up well and cool down afterwards.

prospects.name: Rolling Trail Run 30 mins
prospects.description:
If possible, choose a trail that is rolling terrain or mostly flat in order to keep the effort low-moderate.

​

For help understanding your run workout and calculating your pace zones, please see [this article](https://wahoosystm.com/RunningSessionFAQ).

Learn how to perform your [**Running Drills**](https://support.wahoofitness.com/hc/en-us/articles/4404080091922-Running-Drills) here.

​

**Warm Up**

5 min @ RPE 2 -- >145% of RTP --HR <70% (Z1)

​

**Main Effort**

Interval Duration: 20 mins

Interval Effort: @ RPE 3-4 -- 145-120% of RTP --HR 70-87% (Z2)

Recovery: NA

​

**Cool Down**

5 min @ RPE 2 -- >145% of RTP --HR <70% (Z1)

prospects.name: Cadence Builds
prospects.description:
One of the best sessions for neuromuscular training, this drill asks you to progressively build from a cadence of 90 RPM to your MAX over 30 seconds, recover, and repeat several times. Cadence builds improve how you recruit your leg, gluteal, and core muscles throughout your pedal stroke by progressing to your maximal cadence. By reaching your highest cadence possible, you are training the 'on/off' switch in each muscle group to not only work faster but to have less overlap with your other muscle groups. This session trains your hamstring muscles to 'turn off' when your quads 'turn on' and vice-versa, resulting in a more efficient pedal stroke at both high and low cadences.

​

**LEARN MORE**

Listen to The Knowledge podcast, by Wahoo Sports Science - The Benefits of High Cadence Training: [https://wahoosystm.com/BenefitsofHighCadence](https://wahoosystm.com/BenefitsofHighCadence)

prospects.name: Classic Climbs of France: Col de Braus
prospects.description:
The Col de Braus workout focuses on maintaining a consistent tempo while responding to varied efforts, mimicking real race scenarios. This dynamic training session designed to build endurance and power with a series of specific tempo and surge efforts starts out with a steady tempo pace. At the 2 km mark, we will engage in a 90-second effort as if responding to a breakaway, then return to a strong threshold pace as the profile dips. Throughout the ride, the focus will be on maintaining a high tempo, incorporating ten 3-minute efforts with 30-second out-of-the-saddle bursts.

​

[**Route on Strava**](https://www.strava.com/activities/11556448551)

​

_Your Host: There are few people who know the mountains and roads of Europe better than Wahoo Ambassador Michael Cotty. As founder of The Col Collective, Mike has made a career out of riding, filming, and telling the story of epic rides and mountains across the continent. As your On Location co-creator and host, Mike's engaging character, curious mind, and friendly nature will have you cueing up your next ride with him before you've even finished the cool-down._

prospects.name: Standing Starts
prospects.description:
_Standing Starts_ closely simulates a lifting session on the bike because it requires the engagement of your core, upper body, and lower body. It trains your ability to generate force through the pedals by ensuring you recruit ALL of your muscles to get those cranks turning. No matter your preferred discipline, these efforts are key to teaching your body to recruit all of the muscle fibers in your legs.

​

All of the benefits in this session come from hitting these 20-second efforts as hard as you possibly can. To do that, you need full recovery between each sprint, and you need to respect that recovery. These efforts should see you start at super low RPMs with very high torque. As you start and increase the effort, your cadence will naturally increase. **Your goal is to get your cadence as high as possible by the end of each 20-second effort.** To maximize your muscle recruitment, you want to both push down and pull up on the pedals at the start. Proper core engagement is a must - your legs need a good strong backboard to push against.

​

We understand that not everyone's trainer has the necessary resistance or the required stability to perform this workout as described. If you can't safely stand up, then you can get much of the same benefit by doing these efforts seated. If your trainer can’t handle the rapid change in speed or does not have high enough resistance at a super low cadence, then you can start the efforts at a higher cadence and treat them as “normal” all-out sprints.

prospects.name: Race Simulation Skills - CX
prospects.description:
This skills session is designed to develop skills for a variety of challenging course conditions and mimic scenarios you will encounter on race day. The skills practiced here are done at race pace so you can focus on proper execution while under pressure. To properly complete this ride you will need to find a field with the following features and bring along some equipment:  
  
- A set of stairs, ideally with enough area at the top to practice re-mounting your bike.  
- A flat, open area to practice Figure 8s. Use water bottles or cones to mark the corners.  
- A hill to practice off-camber riding.  
- Barriers about shin high, which can be made from PVC pipe or improvised using your imagination (and a few water bottles).  
- BONUS: an area with sand or deep and loose dirt.  
  
Here’s how to tackle this session:  
  
Warm-up for 10-15 minutes Z1/Z2 spinning, include two 3-5 second hard accelerations.  
  
Hole Shot + Stairs. Complete 2 sets:  
Simulate your race start by lining up 300-400m away from the stairs, in your starting gear and with one foot unclipped.  
Countdown from 10 and you’re OFF! Clip in and complete an all out 15 second effort.  
Work on shifting up smoothly during the effort as you would in a race.  
Continue the effort around Z3/Z4 effort for 60 seconds while riding towards the base of the stairs.  
Dismount and run up the stairs and remount at the top.  
Between the first and second set, do 50-100m of Field Running.  
  
Barriers. Complete 4-6 sets:  
Set up some barriers (you can make a portable set from PVC pipe, or you can use some water bottles and your imagination).  
Starting about 100m out from your barriers, speed towards the barriers at race pace.  
The challenge is to focus on the timing of your dismount and remount and to keep you leg speed high between the barriers in order to maintain the most momentum.  
  
Figure 8s. Complete 5-10 minutes:  
For more info on Figure 8s read “Tips for Figure 8s”.  
Set up 2 bottles about 30m apart and practice your Figure 8s.  
To simulate a race scenario, drive your first 3-4 pedal strokes super hard coming out of each “turn”.  
Alternate seated efforts and standing efforts and experiment with your gearing to find the best fit for your desired cadence and power.  
  
Sand Pit. Complete 5-10 minutes:  
If you also have access to a sand pit then finish with 4-6 efforts through the sand. See “Tips For Sand” to master this skill.  
Finish with 5-10 minutes of easy spinning to cool down.  
  
**Warm-Up **8 minutes @ RPE 3 -- 55% of FTP -- HR <70%  
1 minute @ RPE 3.5 -- 65% of FTP -- HR <75%  
1 minutes @ RPE 4.5 -- 75% of FTP -- HR <75%  
10 seconds @ RPE 10 -- 150% of FTP -- HR < 100%  
50 seconds @ RPE 3 -- 55% of FTP -- HR < 70%  
10 seconds @ RPE 10 -- 150% of FTP -- HR < 100%  
4 minutes @ RPE 3 -- 55% of FTP -- HR <75%  
  
**Main Effort **  
Number of Sets: 4  
Rest Between Sets: 2 minutes  
Interval Repeats per Set: 1  
**Interval**  
8 minutes @ RPE 3 -- 55% of FTP -- HR <70% focusing on assigned skill  
2 minutes @ RPE 2 -- 45% of FTP -- HR <70%  
  
**Extra volume **  
N/A  
  
**Cool Down **  
5 minutes @ RPE 1.5 -- 45% of FTP -- HR <70%

prospects.name: Trails: Sending It 2.5
prospects.description:
**What?'**

A trail ride at a moderate pace, with the inevitable surge in power to tackle a short hill or technical section at race pace. Find a local or favorite trail of yours that’s not too hilly.

​

**Why?**

Focus on targeting your weaknesses during this trail session in order to improve them come race day.

​

**How?**

This is an unstructured ride - start easy to warmup, then let the trail do the thinking today. If you feel good and want to push the pace, go for it! If you find a section that you struggle to hit cleanly, repeat it a few times until you feel comfortable with it. Don’t feel the need to practice every section you struggle with, but use today's ride as an opportunity to practice your skills at race pace!

Keep the effort below 110% of FTP but spend the bulk of the ride at 75-85% of FTP.

​

Make sure to warm up well before hitting race pace and cool down afterwards.

prospects.name: The Frozen Road
prospects.description:
🎬 Film (2017): From the creator: "Self-shot and edited whilst cycling around the world, this film charts a winter journey into the Canadian Arctic as I completed my bike ride up the American continent. Compelled by Jack London’s assertion, that ‘any man who is a man can travel alone,' I sought an adventure of perfect solitude. Yet, as I came to realize, the harsh truths of traveling in such a formidable environment were a long way from the romantic images I’d held of this land. _The Frozen Road_’ is an honest reflection on my solo trip; of the wonder, terror and frustration I experienced when riding through the unforgiving emptiness of one of the world’s ‘last great wildernesses."

​

🚴 Workout: The workout accompanying this film is a recovery session. It's a very low-intensity ride, with your power remaining at or below 50% of FTP (an RPE less than 2.5 on a scale from 1 to 10) and your heart rate in Zone 1. The intensity and cadence targets will vary throughout this session to keep it interesting, but not so much that it distracts you from the story.

​

[Here's how to turn off on-screen graphics for the best viewing experience.](https://wahoosystm.com/HelpCenterInspiration)

prospects.name: Tapers
prospects.description:
When it comes to "peaking", or performing at your absolute best on a given day, the key is nailing your Taper. The term "Taper" refers to how you train in the week or so before your target event to ensure you deliver your best performance. Generally, tapering means reducing your total training volume but continuing to hit some high-intensity efforts. While there are individual variations in the best way to taper, this session has been used by countless professionals leading into the biggest races of their lives -- athletes like World Champions Rohan Dennis and Flora Duffy.

​

With 3 sets of micro-intervals (40/20s, 30/30s, and 20/40s) you will hit your system with just enough intensity to keep your legs sharp and responsive, without adding any real fatigue. Outside of those 3 sets of micro-intervals, this session is purposefully short and easy. This is a preparation session, not a training session! After all, your event is just around the corner and all of the important training is behind you. Riding harder or longer today will do absolutely nothing to increase your fitness by event day; in fact, all that would do is increase your fatigue, which will only hurt your performance. Rather, this session makes sure your body is humming along and ready to perform on the big day.

prospects.name: Costa Blanca: Puerto de la Vall de Ebo (Recharger Ride)
prospects.description:
This is an active recovery ride built with purpose. Low-intensity endurance work is paired with brief high-cadence neuromuscular activations to keep the nervous system awake without creating new fatigue. You’ll stay well below threshold throughout, allowing your body to absorb previous hard sessions and prepare for what’s ahead.

​

Set on the peaceful roads leading to the summit of Port de la Vall d’Ebo, this ride promotes circulation, technique, and mental reset. It’s ideal after race days or big training blocks — a smart session that helps you recover better, so you can train harder tomorrow. No ego, no watts chasing — just intentional recovery done right.

​

[**Wahoo Route**](https://www.strava.com/activities/13996505846)

​

_Your Host: There are few people who know the mountains and roads of Europe better than Wahoo Ambassador Michael Cotty. As founder of The Col Collective, Mike has made a career out of riding, filming, and telling the story of epic rides and mountains across the continent. As your On Location co-creator and host, Mike's engaging character, curious mind, and friendly nature will have you cueing up your next ride with him before you've even finished the cool-down._

prospects.name: Primers
prospects.description: Whether you have a 4DP® fitness test coming up, a group ride you want to smash, that event you have been training all winter for, or even just a fun route you want to have a great ride on, this is the perfect session to do the day before. Unlike other SYSTM sessions, this one should not be viewed as a stand-alone “training” session, but rather, the ace up your sleeve you pull out when that big ride comes around. The key to this session is having you spend just enough time right around threshold, with sufficient recovery between efforts and a handful of sprints to prime all of your systems for tomorrow's event.

prospects.name: Full Frontal (4DP Assessment)
prospects.description:
Full Frontal: The Complete One.

We recommend the Full Frontal 4DP fitness assessment for:

- Experienced riders.
- Athletes with experience pacing maximal efforts / fitness testing.
- Those about to start—or who have just finished—a training plan.

This is our full 4DP fitness test and is the only test that exposes every aspect of your unique physiology in a single hour. Developed by Head of Wahoo Sports Science Coach Neal Henderson, Full Frontal uses the same lab-verified testing protocol that Coach Neal has used at the highest level for over a decade with professional and amateur athletes.

​

This test will provide you with a complete Four-Dimensional Power profile, identify your Rider Type, and tell you exactly what aspects of your fitness you need to focus on to become a more complete cyclist. More importantly, SYSTM will then use your results to set personalized power targets for all of your workouts based on your unique profile, resulting in the most precise, effective workouts available. Your results will also be used to tailor all of your training plans.

​

We recommend re-testing with Full Frontal every 8-12 weeks or as prescribed by your training plan.

​

**LEARN MORE**

Listen to '[Why Fitness Testing Matters](https://the-knowledge-by-wahoo-sports-science.simplecast.com/episodes/testing-testing-1-2-3-why-fitness-testing-matters)' on The Knowledge Podcast by Wahoo Sports Science

​

[Here's some more information on how to get the most from your fitness test.](https://wahoosystm.com/HelpCenterFitnessAssessment)

prospects.name: 03. Establishing the Goal Setting Habit
prospects.description:
**GOAL SETTING**

A clear plan of action is essential to any undertaking. Setting concrete, actionable goals will keep you motivated and on track; whether you’re eyeing the top podium step or the summit of the local climb. We will help assess where you are today, where you want to go, and identify the steps needed to get there.

​

In this module, you will enable consistent progress by creating a habit of identifying monthly and weekly goals, with weekly rewards for achieving those goals.

​

**GET THE WORKBOOK**

If you haven't yet, download the [Mental Training Workbook](https://drive.google.com/file/d/11VIC1ZmuIwDpmv9xdeUrZ6NJ_nZraqPv/view?usp=sharing).

It's a fillable PDF, but you can print it if you prefer to work from a hard copy.

​

​

​

​

prospects.name: 04. Getting Positive
prospects.description:
Thoughts matter. To accomplish big goals you need the ability to maintain a positive mindset, regardless of what life gives you. Here's an overview of the power of maintaining a positive mindset. We’ll introduce specific techniques that will help you identify negative thoughts, see obstacles as opportunities, and take a more positive path forward.

​

**GET THE WORKBOOK**

If you haven't yet, download the [Mental Training Workbook](https://drive.google.com/file/d/11VIC1ZmuIwDpmv9xdeUrZ6NJ_nZraqPv/view?usp=sharing).

It's a fillable PDF, but you can print it if you prefer to work from a hard copy.

prospects.description:
Focus is essential to high performance. Without it, you can become distracted, give in to self-doubt, and struggle to motivate yourself. Strengthen your willpower through a deep understanding of your key motivators and then develop a system to remind you of them on a daily basis.

​

**GET THE WORKBOOK**

If you haven't yet, download the [Mental Training Workbook](https://drive.google.com/file/d/11VIC1ZmuIwDpmv9xdeUrZ6NJ_nZraqPv/view?usp=sharing).

**GET THE WORKBOOK**

You’ll listen more closely to the way you talk to yourself so you can improve that internal dialogue and become your own biggest fan.

prospects.description:
Develop an understanding of why focused concentration is so important to your performance. We will delve into what it means to be in “The Zone," look at the psychology and the physiology of peak performance, and what it takes to get there.

**GET THE WORKBOOK**

prospects.description:
You’ll look back at each of your weekly goals, as well as your overall goal for the month, to see how you did. This is your chance to give yourself a pat on the back, celebrate your successes, and identify how you’re going to do even better.

After looking to see what the past month can teach you, you’re going to turn your attention towards what lies ahead, setting new monthly and weekly goals.

prospects.description:
Let's zoom in on how you actually train, day in and day out. Great training sessions don’t just happen. You have to make a conscious effort, get everything together, then actually do the work. Successful athletes don’t leave their training to chance—they have a specific routine they go through **EVERY. SINGLE. TIME.** The more deliberate you are with your thoughts and actions before, during, and after your workouts, the better your training habit becomes and the greater your progress.

If you haven't yet, download the [Mental Training Workbook](https://drive.google.com/file/d/11VIC1ZmuIwDpmv9xdeUrZ6NJ_nZraqPv/view?usp=sharing).

prospects.name: 14. Future You Is Now
prospects.description:
Here you'll revisit the description of yourself that you wrote when first embarking on this journey. It is an opportunity to see how far you’ve come, but also a chance to look ahead.

​

**GET THE WORKBOOK**

If you haven't yet, download the [Mental Training Workbook](https://drive.google.com/file/d/11VIC1ZmuIwDpmv9xdeUrZ6NJ_nZraqPv/view?usp=sharing).

It's a fillable PDF, but you can print it if you prefer to work from a hard copy.

prospects.name: 15. Kicking Ass in your Sleep Part II
prospects.description:
This visualization exercise is designed to be completed when you’re in bed, ready to fall asleep. You’ll travel from your bedroom to the summit of your Big Mountain.

**GET THE WORKBOOK**

If you haven't yet, download the [Mental Training Workbook](https://drive.google.com/file/d/11VIC1ZmuIwDpmv9xdeUrZ6NJ_nZraqPv/view?usp=sharing).

It's a fillable PDF, but you can print it if you prefer to work from a hard copy.

prospects.name: 16. Regular Monthly Review
prospects.description:
This process mirrors what you did in week five. If you feel like you’re making gains, it’s likely you’ve been getting the work in. If you’re not progressing—if you feel run down—look to see if there are any patterns.

**GET THE WORKBOOK**

If you haven't yet, download the [Mental Training Workbook](https://drive.google.com/file/d/11VIC1ZmuIwDpmv9xdeUrZ6NJ_nZraqPv/view?usp=sharing).

It's a fillable PDF, but you can print it if you prefer to work from a hard copy.

prospects.name: 17. Overcoming Obstacles
prospects.description:
Rainbows? Puppy dogs? Not always. Sometimes things go wrong and this session will get you moving again. As a visualization exercise, this module is meant to be listened to whenever you feel stuck—whether that’s due to an obstacle you can’t see a way around, an injury, a loss of motivation, or any other reason which makes you doubt yourself. Even if you don’t have an obstacle right now, it’s a good idea to go through the module so you know what it’s about and when to use it. It will help you re-focus, reset, and reestablish your confidence in who you are and where you’re headed.

​

**GET THE WORKBOOK**

If you haven't yet, download the [Mental Training Workbook](https://drive.google.com/file/d/11VIC1ZmuIwDpmv9xdeUrZ6NJ_nZraqPv/view?usp=sharing).

It's a fillable PDF, but you can print it if you prefer to work from a hard copy.

prospects.name: 07. Positive Self-Talk
prospects.description:
Improve your confidence and performance through three types of positive self-talk: Motivational, Instructional, and Reward. Here, we’ll look at the subtle and not-so-subtle effects that words have on our attitude and performance. You’ll listen more closely to the way you talk to yourself so you can improve that internal dialogue and become your own biggest fan.

​

**GET THE WORKBOOK**

If you haven't yet, download the [Mental Training Workbook](https://drive.google.com/file/d/11VIC1ZmuIwDpmv9xdeUrZ6NJ_nZraqPv/view?usp=sharing).

It's a fillable PDF, but you can print it if you prefer to work from a hard copy.

​

**LEARN MORE**

Listen to '[The Power of Positive Mental Strategies](https://the-knowledge-by-wahoo-sports-science.simplecast.com/episodes/episode-29-how-to-use-positive-self-talk-to-get-through-tough-moments-on-a-ride-mental-strategies)' on The Knowledge Podcast by Wahoo Fitness.

prospects.name: 08. Improving Focus
prospects.description:
Develop an understanding of why focused concentration is so important to your performance. We will delve into what it means to be in “The Zone," look at the psychology and the physiology of peak performance, and what it takes to get there.

**GET THE WORKBOOK**

If you haven't yet, download the [Mental Training Workbook](https://drive.google.com/file/d/11VIC1ZmuIwDpmv9xdeUrZ6NJ_nZraqPv/view?usp=sharing).

It's a fillable PDF, but you can print it if you prefer to work from a hard copy.

prospects.name: 06. Relaxing to Recover
prospects.description:
Here you will complete a full Progressive Muscle Relaxation session. It’s part guided meditation and part focus exercise. You should listen to this module at least once per week to get in tune with your body, release tension, and maximize recovery.

​

**GET THE WORKBOOK**

If you haven't yet, download the [Mental Training Workbook](https://drive.google.com/file/d/11VIC1ZmuIwDpmv9xdeUrZ6NJ_nZraqPv/view?usp=sharing).

It's a fillable PDF, but you can print it if you prefer to work from a hard copy.

prospects.name: 18. Setting Event Goals
prospects.description:
Get clear on what an event really means to you and what your event-specific goals are.

​

"If you are going to win any battle, you have to do one thing: you have to make the mind run the body."

~ George S. Patton

**GET THE WORKBOOK**

If you haven't yet, download the [Mental Training Workbook](https://drive.google.com/file/d/11VIC1ZmuIwDpmv9xdeUrZ6NJ_nZraqPv/view?usp=sharing).

It's a fillable PDF, but you can print it if you prefer to work from a hard copy.

prospects.name: 19. Planning For Every Event Scenario
prospects.description:
Show up prepared by identifying things that could happen during the course of the event and how to deal with them.

**GET THE WORKBOOK**

If you haven't yet, download the [Mental Training Workbook](https://drive.google.com/file/d/11VIC1ZmuIwDpmv9xdeUrZ6NJ_nZraqPv/view?usp=sharing).

It's a fillable PDF, but you can print it if you prefer to work from a hard copy.

prospects.name: 20. Preparing To Crush It
prospects.description:
This pre-event visualization exercise will help you get in the zone to deliver what athletes and sports psychologists call a “peak performance;” it’s when everything flows and operates at the highest level almost without any effort.

​

**GET THE WORKBOOK**

If you haven't yet, download the [Mental Training Workbook](https://drive.google.com/file/d/11VIC1ZmuIwDpmv9xdeUrZ6NJ_nZraqPv/view?usp=sharing).

It's a fillable PDF, but you can print it if you prefer to work from a hard copy.

prospects.name: 21. How Did it Go?
prospects.description:
Once the dust has settled and your heart rate has returned to normal levels, listen to this module. It's meant to be completed 15 minutes after the event ends. Part two of this exercise is completed the next day when you’ve had time to process and reflect on everything that happened during the event day.

​

**GET THE WORKBOOK**

If you haven't yet, download the [Mental Training Workbook](https://drive.google.com/file/d/11VIC1ZmuIwDpmv9xdeUrZ6NJ_nZraqPv/view?usp=sharing).

It's a fillable PDF, but you can print it if you prefer to work from a hard copy.

prospects.name: 02. Identifying Your Personal Big Mountain
prospects.description:
What - exactly - are you trying to accomplish? When you're ready to answer that question, this module will help you gain clarity on who you are as an athlete and identify your major goal—your Personal Big Mountain.

​

**GET THE WORKBOOK**

If you haven't yet, download the [Mental Training Workbook](https://drive.google.com/file/d/11VIC1ZmuIwDpmv9xdeUrZ6NJ_nZraqPv/view?usp=sharing).

It's a fillable PDF, but you can print it if you prefer to work from a hard copy.

​

**LEARN MORE**

Listen to '[The Importance of SMART Goal Setting](https://the-knowledge-by-wahoo-sports-science.simplecast.com/episodes/start-now-goal-setting-basics)' and '[How to use your personal outlook to set more effective goals](https://the-knowledge-by-wahoo-sports-science.simplecast.com/episodes/know-thyself-how-to-use-your-personal-outlook-to-set-more-effective-goals)' on The Knowledge Podcast by Wahoo Sports Science.

prospects.name: 09. Focus Exercise
prospects.description:
Improve your ability to push away distractions and focus on the task at hand. This five-minute exercise will get you primed and ready to unleash your power from within. That means you should be in your kit and ready to train as soon as you complete this exercise.

prospects.name: Full Body 01
prospects.description:
_Want a strength training routine that covers all the bases? Our Full Body Strength series is exactly what you’re after, offering a well-rounded series of exercises that covers the lower body, core, posterior chain, and upper body. With a substantial progression, there’s enough here to keep you busy -- and improving -- for a very long time._

​

This is the first routine in the Full Body series. It introduces the most basic versions of moves that make up the majority of this program. Some of these moves may seem very basic but we encourage you to focus on perfect form and execution during these early levels so that when we turn up the heat you have things nailed. As you'll see, all the exercises at the lower levels will progress in a similar fashion going forward. We're building strength, but also fine-tuning your nervous system. As the program progresses you'll be asked to complete more difficult variations on each foundational move.

​

As with all the strength training routines, it helps if you’ve done a warm-up before getting started. That can be one of your favorite yoga routines, riding your bike on the trainer for 5-10 minutes, or doing a personal stretching routine.

​

Unsure if this is the correct strength level for you? [Click here for help.](https://wahoosystm.com/HelpCenterChooseStrengthLevel)

​

**Exercises Included:**

- Kneeling Hip Drive - Hands Over Head
- Kneeling Hip Drive - Hands Side to Side
- Hip Bridge with Reps
- Bent Leg Tip at the Hip
- Goblet Squat
- Single-Leg Squat
- Backward Lunge
- Hip Hinge with Reach
- Hip Bridge with Reps
- Push-Up on Knees
- Back Extension
- Quadruped with Leg Lifts
- Plank with Leg Lifts

prospects.name: Full Body 02
prospects.description:
_Want a strength training routine that covers all the bases? Our Full Body Strength series is exactly what you’re after, offering a well-rounded series of exercises that covers the lower body, core, posterior chain, and upper body. With a substantial progression, there’s enough here to keep you busy -- and improving -- for a very long time._

​

In this session, we introduce you to a few more foundational moves. Learn them well as you’ll see them throughout the program as you progress. And as you progress, we'll continue to add more difficult variations on these basics - so develop good habits now for easy mastery down the road.

​

Unsure if this is the correct strength level for you?  [Click here for help.](https://wahoosystm.com/HelpCenterChooseStrengthLevel)

​

**Exercises Included:**

- Kneeling Hip Drive - Hands Over Head
- Kneeling Hip Drive - Hands Side to Side
- Hip Bridge with Reps
- Bent Leg Tip at the Hip
- Forward Lunge
- Lateral Lunge with Extended Hands
- Hip Hinge
- Squat with Wide Stance
- Plank
- Quadruped with Arm Raise
- Side Plank

prospects.name: Posterior Chain Focus 01
prospects.description:
_The primary objective of the Posterior Chain Series is to activate and strengthen the muscles on the back side of your body. This includes everything from your powerful glutes, hamstrings, and calves to the postural muscles of your upper back and neck._

​

Your posterior chain is responsible for back and hip extension as well as knee flexion. It is vital in maintaining optimal posture during cycling and running in addition to water position in swimming. In this first session, we introduce some basic movements that focus on the activation and stabilization of posterior chain muscles. These moves include a combination of eccentric (lengthening), concentric (shortening), and isometric (holding) contractions. They provide your body with the foundation for more demanding moves to come. This is also a good session to come back to if you feel like you could use a quick posterior chain activation or tune-up.

​

Unsure if this is the correct strength level for you?  [Click here for help.](https://wahoosystm.com/HelpCenterChooseStrengthLevel)

​

**Exercises Included:**

- Split Stance Side bend w/ Arms Overhead
- Recoil Hamstring Stretch
- Split Stance Hip Hinges
- Single leg Hip Hinge
- Kneeling Hip Extension
- Quadruped w/ Cervical Extension
- Quadruped Chin Tucks
- Double Leg Hip Bridge
- High Plank w/ Alt. Arm Raise
- High Plank w/ Hip Abduction + Tap
- 45° Reverse Fly w/ Reps
- Lat Press on Wall-Reps
- 90° Reverse Fly w/ Reps
- Overhead Reverse Fly w/ Hold
- KickBacks from Toes
- Hamstring Hip Bridge
- Marching Hip Bridge
- Back Extension w/ opposite arm & leg raise
- Downward Dog
- Pigeon Stretch

prospects.name: Full Body 03
prospects.description:
_Want a strength training routine that covers all the bases? Our Full Body Strength series is exactly what you’re after, offering a well-rounded series of exercises that covers the lower body, core, posterior chain, and upper body. With a substantial progression, there’s enough here to keep you busy -- and improving -- for a very long time._

​

In this session, we begin adding variations to the foundational moves you’ve mastered so far (you’ve mastered them, right?). This will keep challenging you, as will the increases in duration of a few sets -- such as the squats -- so you can complete a few more reps.

prospects.name: Recovery Session A
prospects.description:
These recovery sessions are easy enough that you get the rest you need, but work you hard enough that your body continues to adapt to the new demands you place on it. You might see these sessions as too short and too easy to be beneficial, but just like a proper recovery spin, active recovery is infinitely better than doing nothing at all. Given how short this session is, we strongly recommend also doing a Yoga Session in the app first. Something like Mobilize and Activate, Balance and Agility, or Full Body Mobilization.

​

**Exercises Included**

- Kneeling Hip Drive with Hands Up
- Kneeling Hip Drive with Hands to Side
- High Plank
- Plank
- Hip Bridge
- Bent Leg Tip at the Hip
- Standing Hip Drive with Hands Up
- Standing Hip Drive with Hands to Side

prospects.name: Recovery Session B
prospects.description:
This session is designed to keep your body familiar with the basic movements of strength training without adding any extra fatigue to your system. This keeps your body adapted while allowing it to fully recover. To make the most out of your strength gains, you need to balance the hard work with adequate recovery. Given how short this session is, we strongly recommend completing a supplementary Yoga Session after this video. Something like Improving Posture, Shake Off the Day or Recovery Booster would be perfect.

​

**Exercises Included**

- Kneeling Hip Drive with Hands Over Head
- Kneeling Hip Drive with Hips Side to Side
- High Plank to Pigeon Pose
- Plank with Leg Lifts
- Hip Bridge with Reps
- Fast Lateral Lunges with Knees Up
- Standing Hip Drive with Hands Up
- Standing Hip Drive with Hands Side to Side

prospects.name: Dynamic Focus 01
prospects.description:
_Looking to improve your mobility, stability, power, and coordination? The Dynamic Focus series is a fun, unique, and valuable mix of balance, strength, and jumping exercises that develops your overall coordination and control._

​

As the first session in this progression, we introduce you to an integrated sequence of athletic movements. This mix may feel different and challenging..maybe even fun! Embrace it!

​

Please take your time, especially in this initial session. Start and stop the video to rewatch the demonstrations, if necessary, to ensure you understand the movement and grasp the range of motion. Finally, for the exercises that include a balance component, it will be ideal to keep your gaze fixed on a still object, not your screen.

​

Unsure if this is the correct strength level for you? [Click here for help.](https://wahoosystm.com/HelpCenterChooseStrengthLevel)

​

**Exercises Included:**

- Split Stance Backbend w/ Arms overhead
- Recoil Hamstring Stretch
- Around the clock Heel & Toe Taps
- Alternating-Step Under
- Split Stance Hip Hinges
- Low Skip In Place
- Single leg Hip Hinge
- Tip Toe Walk
- Deep Squat w/Arms Crossed
- Drop to Squat & Hold - Dbl. Leg
- Hop to Opposite Leg w/Hold
- Toe Touch

Our Full Body Strength series is exactly what you’re after, offering a well-rounded series of exercises that covers the lower body, core, posterior chain, and upper body. With a substantial progression, there’s enough here to keep you busy -- and improving -- for a very long time. We recommend you warm up before starting this routine._

​

By now, you should be well on your way to mastering the foundation moves with perfect form. So let’s mix things up a bit and add further variations in order to keep challenging you. We'll also increase the duration of a few sets since your endurance has increased already.

​

Unsure if this is the correct strength level for you?  [Click here for help.](https://wahoosystm.com/HelpCenterChooseStrengthLevel)

prospects.name: Core Focus 01
prospects.description:
_Looking to improve ALL of the muscles that make up your core? You’ve come to the right place. The Core Focus series builds up everything from your hip to your shoulders - front, back, and side._

​

To do this, we’ll take you through a variety of contraction types: eccentric (lengthening), concentric (shortening), and isometric (holding a position). The result? Improved core strength, stability, and endurance. You'll find exercises that carry over into other areas of your body, but all of the moves have a significant impact on your core. Level 1 is ideal for very beginners. Even then, you may find some of these moves challenging if you have never attempted them. That’s ok, take your time and pause the video if you need. Soon you’ll be on your way to mastering your core potential. In addition to a mat, you'll need some open wall space for this routine.

​

Unsure if this is the correct strength level for you? [Click here for help.](https://wahoosystm.com/HelpCenterChooseStrengthLevel)

​

**Exercises Included:**

- High Side Plank w/ Hold
- Quad Toes w/ Alternate Arm Raise

- Bird Dogs
- Back Extension with Hold

​

You’re progressing quite nicely. So nicely, in fact, that you’re ready for a more demanding session. This workout includes compound sets which are more difficult but, most importantly, more beneficial than simply doing more sets of a single move. This is because your nervous system has to work overtime to cope with the variety. The number of reps per set is also higher, which will help drive continuous improvement.

Since this is a longer session, you may experience considerable fatigue on your first time through. As a result, pay more attention to your form. Your body will want to use as little energy as possible, which can lead to some bad habits when hitting rep after rep of a single move. Thankfully, the constant variation of the compound sets forces you to stay engaged and helps you keep solid form from start to finish.

_Looking to improve ALL of the muscles that make up your core? You’ve come to the right place. The Core Focus series builds up everything from your hip to your shoulders - front, back, and side._

​

We’re getting more complicated now, and this session includes rotational movements which demand power and control against an external load. The combination and order of movements will challenge your core strength and endurance while improving your ability to maintain stability and control when tired.

​

Unsure if this is the correct strength level for you?  [Click here for help.](https://wahoosystm.com/HelpCenterChooseStrengthLevel)

prospects.name: Full Body 16
prospects.description:
_Want a strength training routine that covers all the bases? Our Full Body Strength series is exactly what you’re after, offering a well-rounded series of exercises that covers the lower body, core, posterior chain, and upper body. With a substantial progression, there’s enough here to keep you busy -- and improving -- for a very long time._

​

By this point, you’re no longer struggling with single-leg balance and stability, which allows us to really focus on building raw muscular endurance in your lower body. Additionally, this routine will place greater demands on your upper body and core than any previous session has. Not only do you have 10+ minutes dedicated to the muscles above your hips, but the progression of High Planks and High Side Planks means that even the “core-work” moves have a difficult upper-body component. We’re also going to ask a lot of your movement stabilization muscles -- it’s about time they were held to account.

​

Unsure if this is the correct strength level for you?  [Click here for help.](https://wahoosystm.com/HelpCenterChooseStrengthLevel)

​

**Exercises Included:**

- Kneeling Hip Drive with Hands Over Head
- Kneeling Hip Drive with Hips Side to Side
- Hip Bridge
- Reverse Lunge with Hands Over Head
- Reverse Lunge with Hands to Side
- Bent Leg Tip at the Hip
- Single-Leg Squat with Hands Forward + Shoulder Press
- Single-Leg Squat with Opposite Reach + Shoulder Press
- Bulgarian Squat

- Backward Lunge

prospects.name: Upper Body Focus 04
prospects.description:
_The primary goal of this series is to increase strength in the major muscles of the chest, back, shoulders and arms. We’ll also focus on improving mobility, stability, and flexibility in the upper body. So get ready for great body-weight-based routines that focus on quality repetitions, endurance holds, and range of motion challenges._

​

Ready to work hard? Level 4 will not disappoint in terms of overloading your chest, back, shoulders, arms, and core. Among other challenges, this workout includes two new tempo repetitions and work with resistance bands. The tempo training increases muscle activity as you react to sudden starts and stops while the resistance bands demand consistent focus with tension in all directions. And if you fall in love with any of these fantastic exercises, don’t worry -- you’re quite likely to see them again before the routine is over.

​

Unsure if this is the correct strength level for you? [Click here for help.](https://wahoosystm.com/HelpCenterChooseStrengthLevel)

​

- Overhead Shoulder Rolls w/ Stick
- Shoulder Rolls Around the body
- Tempo Pushup Narrow
- Standing T-Spine Rotation
- Overhead Reverse Fly Reps
- 45° Reverse Fly w/ Reps
- 90° Reverse Fly w/ Reps
- Low to High Plank Pushups
- High Side Plank w/ Rotation
- Low Plank w/ Scapular Press
- Wide Pushup

prospects.name: Dynamic Focus 05
prospects.description:
_Looking to improve your mobility, stability, power, and coordination? The Dynamic Focus series is a fun, unique, and valuable mix of balance, strength, and jumping exercises that_ _increase performance through stability, power, and coordination._

​

This level will really test your neuromuscular coordination and muscular power. We’ll do that through a tough mix of controlled, static holds as well as explosive, dynamic jumps. You may find yourself cardiovascularly challenged, which is great! Push yourself with quality movements and then recover with the mobility activities.

prospects.name: Full Body 01
prospects.description:
_Want a strength training routine that covers all the bases? Our Full Body Strength series is exactly what you’re after, offering a well-rounded series of exercises that covers the lower body, core, posterior chain, and upper body. With a substantial progression, there’s enough here to keep you busy -- and improving -- for a very long time._

​

This is the first routine in the Full Body series. It introduces the most basic versions of moves that make up the majority of this program. Some of these moves may seem very basic but we encourage you to focus on perfect form and execution during these early levels so that when we turn up the heat you have things nailed. As you'll see, all the exercises at the lower levels will progress in a similar fashion going forward. We're building strength, but also fine-tuning your nervous system. As the program progresses you'll be asked to complete more difficult variations on each foundational move.

​

As with all the strength training routines, it helps if you’ve done a warm-up before getting started. That can be one of your favorite yoga routines, riding your bike on the trainer for 5-10 minutes, or doing a personal stretching routine.

​

Unsure if this is the correct strength level for you? [Click here for help.](https://wahoosystm.com/HelpCenterChooseStrengthLevel)

​

**Exercises Included:**

- Kneeling Hip Drive - Hands Over Head
- Kneeling Hip Drive - Hands Side to Side
- Hip Bridge with Reps
- Bent Leg Tip at the Hip
- Goblet Squat
- Single-Leg Squat
- Backward Lunge
- Hip Hinge with Reach
- Hip Bridge with Reps
- Push-Up on Knees
- Back Extension
- Quadruped with Leg Lifts
- Plank with Leg Lifts

We know you’re up for the challenge so, let’s do it!

prospects.name: Dynamic Focus 02
prospects.description:
_Looking to improve your mobility, stability, power, and coordination? The Dynamic Focus series is a fun, unique, and valuable mix of balance, strength, and jumping exercises that_ _increase performance through stability, power, and coordination._

​

Now that you’ve completed Level 1, it’s time to add a layer of neuromuscular coordination. This sequence includes balance, unilateral drills, lower body strength, and jumping exercises - and combinations of those. You’ll even complete integrated exercises which involve single-leg challenges in various directions. Focus on controlled deliberate movements and solid landings to master this session.

​

Unsure if this is the correct strength level for you? [Click here for help.](https://wahoosystm.com/HelpCenterChooseStrengthLevel)

​

**Exercises Included:**

- Split Stance Backbend w/ Arms Overhead
- Around the Clock Heel & Toe Taps
- Step Unders
- Step Overs
- Recoil Hamstring Stretch
- Side Lunge to Knee Lift w/ Hold
- Split Stance Hip Hinges
- Single leg Hip Hinge
- Tip Toe Walk
- Deep Squat w/Arms Crossed
- Low Skip In Place
- Drop to Squat & Hold
- Single-Leg Hop forward-Backward-Hold
- Pogo Jumps
- Hop to Opp Leg w/Hold
- Double Leg Hop - Continuous - Square Pattern
- Pigeon Stretch
- Inchworm From Plank

prospects.name: Lower Body Focus 01
prospects.description:
_Want to develop more lower body stability, strength, and power? This series takes you through a progression of exercises focused directly on your legs and hips. To mix things up a bit, we’ll occasionally throw in a few upper body, core, and mobility moves to give those legs a break._

​

Think of Lower Body Focus 1 as a taster of a wide variety of moves that you’ll see throughout the series. This gives you a chance to develop optimal movement patterns, improve range of motion and work on your unilateral stability before moving onto more demanding sessions. These workouts are ideal for all sports that require both technical control and explosive movements. Time to Rock!

​

Unsure if this is the correct strength level for you?  [Click here for help.](https://wahoosystm.com/HelpCenterChooseStrengthLevel)

​

**Included Exercises**:

- Split Stance Backbend w/ Arms overhead-Right
- Recovery
- Around the clock Heel & Toe Taps
- Recoil Hamstring Stretch
- Single leg Hip Hinge
- Tip Toe Walk
- Bulgarian Lunge
- Deep Squat w/Arms Crossed

- Hop to Opposite Leg w/Hold-Alternating
- Split Squats
- Hip Hinges
- Side Lunge to Knee Lift w/ Hold
- Kneeling Hip Extension
- Hip Bridge w/ Knee Squeeze
- Hamstring Hip Bridge
- Inchworm from plank
- Pigeon Stretch

prospects.name: Core Focus 01
prospects.description:
_Looking to improve ALL of the muscles that make up your core? You’ve come to the right place. The Core Focus series builds up everything from your hip to your shoulders - front, back, and side._

​

To do this, we’ll take you through a variety of contraction types: eccentric (lengthening), concentric (shortening), and isometric (holding a position). The result? Improved core strength, stability, and endurance. You'll find exercises that carry over into other areas of your body, but all of the moves have a significant impact on your core. Level 1 is ideal for very beginners. Even then, you may find some of these moves challenging if you have never attempted them. That’s ok, take your time and pause the video if you need. Soon you’ll be on your way to mastering your core potential. In addition to a mat, you'll need some open wall space for this routine.

​

Unsure if this is the correct strength level for you? [Click here for help.](https://wahoosystm.com/HelpCenterChooseStrengthLevel)

​

**Exercises Included:**

- Split Stance Side Bend w/ Arms Overhead
- Downward Dog
- Quadruped T-Spine Rotation
- Back Extension w/ opp arm & leg raise
- Hamstring Hip Bridge
- Oblique Leg Lifts

prospects.name: Recovery Session B
prospects.description:
This session is designed to keep your body familiar with the basic movements of strength training without adding any extra fatigue to your system. This keeps your body adapted while allowing it to fully recover. To make the most out of your strength gains, you need to balance the hard work with adequate recovery. Given how short this session is, we strongly recommend completing a supplementary Yoga Session after this video. Something like Improving Posture, Shake Off the Day or Recovery Booster would be perfect.

​

**Exercises Included**

- Kneeling Hip Drive with Hands Over Head
- Kneeling Hip Drive with Hips Side to Side
- High Plank to Pigeon Pose
- Plank with Leg Lifts
- Hip Bridge with Reps
- Fast Lateral Lunges with Knees Up
- Standing Hip Drive with Hands Up
- Standing Hip Drive with Hands Side to Side

prospects.name: Recovery Session A
prospects.description:
These recovery sessions are easy enough that you get the rest you need, but work you hard enough that your body continues to adapt to the new demands you place on it. You might see these sessions as too short and too easy to be beneficial, but just like a proper recovery spin, active recovery is infinitely better than doing nothing at all. Given how short this session is, we strongly recommend also doing a Yoga Session in the app first. Something like Mobilize and Activate, Balance and Agility, or Full Body Mobilization.

​

**Exercises Included**

- Kneeling Hip Drive with Hands Up
- Kneeling Hip Drive with Hands to Side
- High Plank
- Plank
- Hip Bridge
- Bent Leg Tip at the Hip
- Standing Hip Drive with Hands Up
- Standing Hip Drive with Hands to Side

prospects.name: Completed Level 5 Strength
prospects.description:
Congratulations on completing Level 5 Strength!  
  
​

prospects.name: Total Newbie Yoga
prospects.description: Yoga-curious but don't know where to start? This session is a great place to dip your toes in. This easy, basic routine will introduce you to some simple foundational moves while giving you a little stretch and some light strength work at the same time. Think of it as the gateway drug to bringing yoga into your life.

prospects.name: Basic Yoga Poses
prospects.description: Throughout the SYSTM yoga program there are several basic, foundational moves that form the core of the routines. This session takes you through those moves in detail so you can master them and their more difficult variations.

prospects.name: Super Easy Stretch Routine I
prospects.description: Are you looking for a simple stretching routine you can do on a regular basis? New to yoga? Designed for yoga beginners, this gentle yoga session will get you on the road to a more flexible you. You've said for years you'd start stretching. Now's your chance.

prospects.name: Loosen Neck and Shoulders
prospects.description: Cycling can put a lot of strain on your neck and shoulders, especially if you spend a lot of time down in the drops or in an aero position. This session will help loosen your neck and shoulders with a series of exercises that will release tension and have you feeling relaxed and ready to hit it again.

prospects.name: Chest & Shoulder Strength
prospects.description:
This yoga sequence is designed to strengthen the upper body, targeting the shoulders, chest, triceps, and core. It's an ideal routine to practice in the morning or before a workout to activate muscles throughout the body. The intensity can be increased by lifting the knees during push-ups, providing a challenge to work towards.

​

The objectives are to strengthen the shoulders, chest, triceps, and core, practice synchronizing breath and movement, and potentially alleviate lower back pain.

​

**Poses in this session:**

- Mountain
- Half Sun Salutations
- Triceps Push-Ups
- Plank
- Child
- Downward Dog
- Puppy
- Chest Stretch
- Triceps Stretch
- Final Resting Pose

prospects.name: End Of Day Stretch
prospects.description:
This slow and stretchy sequence is ideal for practicing at the end of a long day at work or after travel. It focuses on opening up the chest and shoulders, stretching the neck and forearms, and releasing tension in the calves, hamstrings, hips, and lower back. These poses can also be used after a workout for a comprehensive full-body stretch.

​

The objectives are to stretch the neck, shoulders, triceps, chest, and forearms; release tension in the lower back, hips, hamstrings, calves, ankles, and feet; transition the body into parasympathetic "rest or digest" mode after exercise; and help alleviate lower and mid back pain.

​

**Poses in this session:**

- Puppy
- Screaming Toe
- Neck Stretch
- Ankle Stretch
- Chest Stretch
- Forearm Stretch
- Downward Dog
- Revolved Standing Forward Bend
- Low Lunge Chest Opener
- Dead Pigeon
- Reclining Spinal Twist

prospects.name: Morning Yoga Routine
prospects.description: In this sequence, we start with a short breathing exercise to relax the body and calm the mind, then mobilize joints throughout the body. From there we move into deeper stretches for the hips and hamstrings and finish with a short meditation.

prospects.name: Basic Yoga Poses
prospects.description: Throughout the SYSTM yoga program there are several basic, foundational moves that form the core of the routines. This session takes you through those moves in detail so you can master them and their more difficult variations.

prospects.name: Neck and Upper Back Recovery
prospects.description: In this Beginner sequence, we improve mobility in the neck, shoulders, upper and mid-back, open up the chest and shoulders and relieve tension at the lower back to help alleviate neck, shoulder, and interscapular pain. You can practice it in the morning or the evening.

prospects.name: Recovery Booster
prospects.description: It may seem counterintuitive, but it's during recovery when you actually get stronger and consolidate the gains you've made while training. Without proper recovery, you won't improve. This session helps boost your recovery time, relaxing you and ensuring you give your body the chance to grow stronger.

prospects.name: Hip Flexor and Groin Recovery
prospects.description: In this Beginner sequence, we release the hip flexors and groin and stretch the hamstrings and calves. It's a great session to do after a workout or in the evening to prevent and alleviate lower back pain.

prospects.name: Super Easy Stretch Routine I
prospects.description: Are you looking for a simple stretching routine you can do on a regular basis? New to yoga? Designed for yoga beginners, this gentle yoga session will get you on the road to a more flexible you. You've said for years you'd start stretching. Now's your chance.

prospects.name: Foot & Ankle Recovery
prospects.description:
In this restorative sequence, the focus is on mobilizing the toes, feet, and ankles, stretching the calves and hamstrings, and opening up the hips. The session begins with a calming breathing technique, followed by a simple foot massage to introduce movement from the toes up to the heel. With increased range of motion, the routine progresses to gentle, dynamic stretches for the calves, hamstrings, and hips. Since feet are often neglected and subjected to high demands from activities like running or cycling, practicing this sequence at least once a week helps to rebalance and address this issue.

​

The objectives are to improve mobility in the feet and ankles, stretch the calves and hamstrings, and open up the hips.

​

**Poses in this session:**

- Easy Seat
- Box Breathing
- Foot Massage
- Downward Dog
- Screaming Toe
- Yoga Squat
- Ankle Stretch
- Ankle Mobilisations
- Windscreen Wipers

prospects.name: Post-Workout Cool-Down
prospects.description: This gentle cool-down is designed to completely unwind you after your ride…and potentially send you to sleep. We move systematically through the body, loosening up and stretching out tight muscles. Try to stay relaxed throughout while breathing in and out through your nose.

prospects.name: Lower Back Recovery
prospects.description: In this Beginner sequence, we release tension in the hips—the groin, glutes, piriformis, TFL, and external hip rotators, stretch the calves and hamstrings and re-align the pelvis. It's a great session to practice in the morning or the evening to prevent and alleviate lower back pain.

prospects.name: Thoracic Recovery
prospects.description: In this Beginner sequence, we improve thoracic and shoulder mobility, open up the chest and stretch the lats, shoulders, triceps, calves, and hamstrings to improve posture, facilitate better breathing and help to alleviate upper back, interscapular, and neck pain. You can practice it in the morning or the evening.

prospects.name: Morning Yoga Routine
prospects.description: In this sequence, we start with a short breathing exercise to relax the body and calm the mind, then mobilize joints throughout the body. From there we move into deeper stretches for the hips and hamstrings and finish with a short meditation.

prospects.name: Supple Spine & Hips
prospects.description:
This classic yoga sequence enhances mobility in the spine and hips while stretching the calves, hamstrings, hip flexors, and lower back. As you become familiar with the routine, you can begin to focus on synchronizing your breath with your movements, aiming to use nasal breathing as much as possible. It is an excellent practice for the morning to warm up and improve focus, or it can be done directly after a workout to help prevent extreme muscle stiffness.

​

The objectives are to improve mobility in the spine and hips, stretch the calves, hamstrings, hip flexors, and lower back, practice synchronizing breath and movement, and potentially alleviate lower back pain.

​

**Poses in this session:**

- Mountain
- Half Sun Salutations
- Downward Dog
- Crescent Lunge
- Bridge
- Reclining Spinal Twist
- Final Resting Pose

prospects.description:
In this video, we focus on mobilizing the wrists, elbows, shoulders, neck, spine, hips, ankles, and toes to enhance overall mobility throughout the body. It is an excellent routine to practice in the morning or evening to alleviate stiffness.

​

The objectives are to increase mobility in the wrists, elbows, shoulders, neck, spine, hips, and ankles.

​

**Poses in this session:**

prospects.description:
This video is designed to alleviate tightness in the lower back by releasing tension in the lower back, glutes, piriformis, groin, hamstrings, and calves through a series of reclining hip-opening poses combined with deep, diaphragmatic breathing.

​

The objectives are to stretch the lower back, glutes, piriformis, groin, hamstrings, and calves, improve mobility in the hips and spine, and help alleviate lower back pain.

​

**Poses in this session:**

- Wind-Relieving
- Reclining Spinal Twist

- Happy Baby

prospects.name: Breathing to Crush Them
prospects.description: This is the breathing technique used by Navy Seals to help them focus and find calm before major operations. Learn and use this technique before heading into your own major events and races.

prospects.name: Improving Posture
prospects.description: Most cyclists suffer from rounded shoulders and a curved spine as a result of hours spent in the riding position. This series will release tension in your upper back and get you standing up straight and powerful again.

prospects.name: Super Easy Stretch Routine I
prospects.description: Are you looking for a simple stretching routine you can do on a regular basis? New to yoga? Designed for yoga beginners, this gentle yoga session will get you on the road to a more flexible you. You've said for years you'd start stretching. Now's your chance.

prospects.name: Side Bends
prospects.description: If you're pushing yourself hard, it's likely you're getting stiff and sore all over. Side bends are one of my favorite ways to deal with general soreness. They're also perfect for cyclists who typically suffer from poor lateral flexibility.

prospects.name: Full Body Mobility
prospects.description: This sequence is designed to improve the range of motion throughout the body, focusing on the spine, shoulders, and hips. It combines twists, side bends, and balance poses to enhance total body flexibility and agility.

prospects.name: Yoga for Travel
prospects.description: If you're traveling and will be off your bike for some time, you might feel that all is lost. But we've created a routine for travelers to keep you balanced, loose, and strong. Do this daily while on the road so you'll be in top condition when you can get back home.

prospects.name: Super Easy Stretch Routine II
prospects.description: You've just finished a difficult training session. You probably just want to curl up in a ball, but to make sure your body stays limber and flexible this sequence will stretch you out and open you up. You'll be ready to hit it again in no time.

prospects.name: Upper Body Strength
prospects.description: Those things you use to type and lift up your coffee cup? Yeah, those could be a bit stronger. So it's time to build strength in your upper body—in the hands, wrists, arms, shoulders, chest, and core. It is based around Sun Salutation, a yoga sequence that builds strength, increases power, and improves endurance.

prospects.name: The One For Your Hips
prospects.description:
This classic yoga sequence is designed to enhance hip mobility by stretching the hip flexors, glutes, groin, hamstrings, and calves through a series of static poses. The routine emphasizes releasing tension with each exhalation. It is particularly effective for alleviating lower back pain and improving hip range of motion. This sequence can be practiced at any time of day.

​

The objectives are to improve hip mobility, stretch the hip flexors, glutes, groin, hamstrings, and calves, practice nasal breathing with movement, and potentially alleviate lower back pain.

​

**Poses in this session:**

- Mountain
- Low Lunge
- Downward Dog Split
- Lizard
- Pigeon
- Happy Baby
- Final Resting Pose

prospects.name: Core Strengtheners I
prospects.description: The power to to put watts to the pedals comes not just from your legs, but from your core. When your core is strong and stable, you can generate more power, more efficiently. You'll also suffer less back pain. With those goals in mind, this sequence strengthens the abs, obliques, and lower back.

prospects.description: Cyclists are notorious for poor hamstring and calf flexibility. But these muscles can only be properly engaged when they're flexible. This series will increase your range of motion, boosting performance while helping you avoid injury.

prospects.name: Scapular Stability
prospects.description: In this Beginner / Intermediate sequence, we stabilize the muscles that support your shoulder blades, activate the posterior chain, strengthen the core and stretch the chest and fronts of the shoulders. This helps reduce your risk of neck and shoulder injury, alleviate neck and interscapular pain, and improve your posture. It's a great session to do in the morning or before a workout.

This sequence is designed to activate your posterior chain—the calves, hamstrings, glutes, lower, upper, and mid-back, as well as your core—the abs and obliques. It’s crucial that you engage these muscles before every ride to give you maximum power, speed, and endurance on the bike.
